column1: Here''s a dilemma for you... With all your honor and dignity what would you do? This test only has one question
column2:
but it''s a very important one.

\n

Please don''t answer it without giving it some serious thought. By giving an honest answer you will be able to test where you stand morally.

\n

The test features an unlikely
column3: completely fictional situation
column4: where you will have to make a decision one way or the other. Remember that your answer needs to be honest
column5:
yet spontaneous. Please scroll down slowly and consider each line - this is important for the test to work accurately.

\n

You''re in Florida...In Miami
column6: to be exact. There is great chaos going on around you
column7: caused by a hurricane and severe floods. There are huge masses of water all over you. You are a CNN photographer and you are in the middle of this great disaster. The situation is nearly hopeless. You''re trying to shoot very impressive photos. There are houses and people floating around you
column8:
disappearing into the water. Nature is showing all its destructive power and is ripping everything away with it.

\n

Suddenly you see a man in the water
column9: he is fighting for his life
column10:
trying not to be taken away by the masses of water and mud. You move closer. Somehow the man looks familiar.

\n

Suddenly you know who it is -- it''s George W. Bush!

\n

At the same time you notice that the raging waters are about to take him away
column11: forever. You have two options. You can save him or you can take the best photo of your life. So you can save the life of George W. Bush
column12: or you can shoot a Pulitzer prize winning photo
column13:
a unique photo displaying the death of one of the world''s most powerful men.

\n

And here''s the question (please give an honest answer):

\n

Would you select color film
column14: or rather go with the simplicity of classic black and white?

column1:
1. Did you hear about the new sushi bar that caters exclusively
to lawyers? It''s called
column2:
Sosumi.

2. Did you hear that the Post Office just recalled their latest
stamps? They had pictures of lawyers on them...and people
couldn''t figure out which side to spit on.

3. How are an apple and a lawyer alike? They both look good
hanging from a tree.

4. How can a pregnant woman tell that she''s carrying a future
lawyer? She has an uncontrollable craving for bologna.

5. How does an attorney sleep? First he lies on one side
column3:
then
he lies on the other.

\n

6. How many lawyer jokes are there? Only three. The rest are
true stories.

\n

7. How many lawyers does it take to screw in a light bulb?
Three
column4:
One to climb the ladder. One to shake it. And one to sue
the ladder company.

\n

8. If a lawyer and an IRS agent were both drowning
column5:
and you
could only save one of them
column6:
would you go to lunch or read your
newspaper?

9. What are lawyers good for? They make used car salesmen look
good.

10. What did the terrorist that hijacked a jumbo-jet full of
lawyers do? He threatened to release one every hour if his
demands were not met.

11. What do dinosaurs and decent lawyers have in common? They
are both extinct.

12. What do lawyers and sperm have in common? It takes 300
column7:
000
of them to make one human being.

13. What do you call 25 attorneys buried up to their chins in
cement? Not enough cement.

14. What do you call 25 skydiving lawyers? A round of Skeet.

15.What do you call a lawyer gone bad? Senator.

15. What do you call a lawyer with an IQ of 50? Your Honor.

16. What do you throw to a drowning lawyer? His partners.

17. What does a lawyer do after sex? Pays the bill.

18. What does a lawyer get when you give him Viagra? Taller.

19. What''s brown and looks really good on a lawyer? A Doberman.

20. What''s the difference between a lawyer and a liar? The
pronunciation.

21. What''s the difference between a lawyer and a prostitute? The
prostitute stops screwing you after you are dead.

22. What''s the difference between a lawyer and a vulture? The
lawyer gets frequent flyer miles.

23. What''s the difference between a mosquito and a lawyer? One
is a blood-sucking parasite
column8:
the other is an insect.

24. Where can you find a good lawyer? The nearest cemetery.

25. Why did God make snakes just before lawyers? To practice.

26. Why does California have the most lawyers in the country
column9:
and New Jersey have the most toxic waste sites? New Jersey got
first choice.

column1:
A teacher in a small Vermont town asks her class how many of them are John Kerry fans.

\n

Not really knowing what a John Kerry fan is
column2: but wanting to be liked by the teacher
column3:
all the kids raise their hands except one boy.

\n

The teacher asks Johnny why he has decided to be different.

\n

Johnny says
column4:
"I''m not a John Kerry fan."

\n

The teacher says
column5:
"Why aren''t you a John Kerry fan?"

\n

Johnny says
column6:
"I''m a George Bush fan."

\n

The teacher asks why he''s a George Bush fan.

\n

The boy says
column7: "Well
column8: my mom''s a George Bush fan and my dad''s a George Bush fan
column9:
so I''m a George Bush fan!"

\n

The teacher is kind of angry
column10: because this IS Vermont
column11: so she asks
column12: "What if your mom was a moron and your dad was an idiot
column13:
what would that make you?"

\n

Johnny says
column14: "That would make me a John Kerry fan."

column1: A blonde bought two horses
column2:
and could never remember which was
which.

A neighbor suggested that she cut the tail of one horse and that
worked great until the other horse got his tail caught in a
bush. It tore just right and looked exactly like the other
horse''s tail and our friend was stuck again.

The neighbor suggested her to notch the ear of one horse. That
worked fine until the other horse caught his ear on a barbed
wire fence. Once again the blonde couldn''t tell them apart.

The neighbor suggested she measure the horses for height. When
she did
column3:

pack. The Washington Post february 4, 1988 I BelieveThis is more commentary than humor, but what the heck...------------------------------------I believe the president. I have always believed him. I believed him when he said he had never been drafted in the Vietnam War and I believed him when he said he had forgotten to mention that he had been drafted in the Vietnam War. I believed him when he said he hadn''t had sex with Gennifer Flowers and I believe him now, when he reportedly says he did.I believe the president did not rent out the Lincoln Bedroom, did not sell access to himself and the vice president to hundreds of well-heeled special pleaders and did not supervise the largest, most systematic money-laundering operation in campaign finance history, collecting more than $ 3 million in illegal and improper donations. I believe that Charlie Trie and James Riady were motivated by nothing but patriotism for their adopted country.I believed Vice President Gore when he said that he had made dunning calls to political contributors ''on a few occasions'' from his White House office, and I believed when he said that, actually, ''a few'' meant 46. I believe in no controlling legal authority.I believe Bruce Babbitt when he says that the $ 286,000 contributed the DNC by Indian tribes opposed to granting a casino license to rival tribes had nothing to do with his denial of the license. I believed the secretary when he said that he had not been instructed this matter by then-White House deputy chief of staff Harold Ickes. I believed him when he said that he had told lobbyist and friend Paul Eckstein that Ickes had told him to move on the casino decision, but that he had been lying to Eckstein. I agree with the secretary that it is an outrage that anyone would question his integrity. I believe in the Clinton Standard of adherence to the campaign finance and bribery laws, enunciated by the president on March 7, 1997: ''I don''t believe you can find any evidence of the fact that I had changed government policy solely because of a contribution.'' I note with approval the use of the word ''evidence'' and also the use of the word ''solely.'' I believe that it is proper to change government policy to address the concerns of people who have given the president money, as long as nobody can find evidence of this being the sole reason. I believe the president has lived up to his promise to preside over the most ethical administration in American history. I believe that indicted former agriculture secretary Mike Espy did not accept $35,000 in illegal favors from Tyson Foods and other regulated businesses. I believe that indicted former housing secretary Henry Cisneros did not lie to the FBI and tell others to lie to cover up $ 250,000 in blackmail payments to his former mistress. I believe that convicted former associate attorney general Webster Hubbell was not involved in the obstruction of justice when the president''s minions arranged for Hubbell to receive $ 400,000 in sweetheart consulting deals at a time when he was reneging on his promise to cooperate with Kenneth Starr''s Whitewater investigation. I believe Paula Jones is a cheap tramp who was asking for it. I believe Kathleen Willey is a cheap tramp who was asking for it. I believe Monica Lewinsky is a cheap tramp who was asking for it. I believe Lewinsky was fantasizing in her 20 hours of conversation in which she reportedly detailed her sexual relationship with the president and begged Linda Tripp to join her in lying about the relationship. I believe that any gifts, correspondence, telephone calls and the 37 post-employment White House visits that may have passed between Lewinsky and the president are evidence only of a platonic relationship; such innocent intimate friendships are quite common between middle-aged married men and young single women, and also between presidents of the United States and White House interns. I see nothing suspicious in the report that the president''s intimate, Vernon Jordan, arranged a $ 40,000-per-year job for Lewinsky shortly after she signed but before she filed an affidavit saying she had not had sex with the president. Nor do I read anything into the fact that the ambassador to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, visited Lewinsky at the Watergate to offer her a job. I believe the instructions Lewinsky gave Tripp informing her on how to properly perjure herself in the Willey matter simply wrote themselves.I believe that The Washington Post, the Los Angeles Times, The New York Times, Newsweek, Time, U.S. News & World Report, ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN, PBS and NPR are all part of a vast right-wing conspiracy. Especially NPR. A first grade teacher in the conservative Midwest is explaining to her class that she is a Republican and how nice it is that a new Republican president has taken office. She asks her students to raise their hands if they, too, are Republicans and support George Bush.

\n

Everyone in class raises their hands except one little girl. Mary
column9: says the teacher with surprise, why didn''t you raise your hand?"  Because I''m not a Republican
column10: says Mary. Well
column11: what are you?" asks the teacher.  "I''m a Democrat and proud of it
column12:
replies the little girl.

\n

The teacher cannot believe her ears. My goodness
column13: Mary
column14: why are you a Democrat?" she asks. "Well
column15: my momma and papa are Democrats
column16: so I''m a Democrat
column17:
too."

\n

"Well
column18: says the teacher in an annoyed tone, that''s no reason for you to be a Democrat. You don''t always have to be like your parents. What if your momma was a criminal and your papa was a criminal
column19: too
column20:
what would you be then?"

\n

Mary smiled. "Then we''d be Republicans."

column1:
Good evening my fellow Americans.

\n

First
column2:
I want to pass on my condolences to the people of New
York and all Americans that are hurting in this tragic time. You
can rest assured that anything and everything that can be done
to assure the safety of our country will be done. This is the
greatest country in the world and we will get through this
trying time. Now is the time for all people to set aside our
petty differences and show the world that no one or nothing can
destroy the fortitude of the American people.

\n

To the people responsible for today''s tragedy
column3:
I say this: Are
you fucking kidding me? Are the turbans on your heads wrapped
too tight? Have you gone too long without a bath? Do you not
know who you are fucking with? Americans are so hungry to kill
column4:
that we shoot at each other every day. We will relish that
opportunity for new targets for our aggression. Have you
forgotten history? What happened to the last people that started
fucking around with us? Remember the little yellow bastards over
in Japan? We slapped them all over the Pacific and roasted about
2 million of them in their own back yard. That''s what we in
America call a big ass barbecue. Ever seen Texas on a map? Ever
wonder why it''s so big? Because we wanted it that way
column5:
Mexico
started jacking around with the Alamo and now they cut our
lawns. England? We sent them packing.

\n

Ask your buddy Saddam about fucking with the good ''ole USA. The
only reason he got away the first time is because it''s too hard
to shoot someone when you''re doubled over laughing at them. Our
soldiers aren''t trained to laugh and shoot at the same time. Now
he couldn''t stop a pack of cub scouts from taking over his
shitty little country.

\n

Trust us
column6:
Afghanistan will end up a giant kitty litter box. Go
ahead and try to hide
column7:
Bin Laden. There''s not a hole deep enough
or a mountain high enough that''s going to keep your camel riding
asses safe. We will bomb every inch of the country that harbors
him
column8:
his camps and any place that looks and even smells like he
was there. Hell
column9:
we might even drop a few bombs on people that
have pissed us off in the past. This is America. We kick ass.
This is what we do. Go ahead and laugh now
column10:
but the Tomahawks
are coming and we will smoke your sorry asses.

\n

God bless America!

a fraud.

3. Bring a dog to the funeral and have him play dead.

5. Ask the widow to pose for a picture with her arm around the
coffin
column3: and then stall for a long time
column4:
pretending you can''t get
the camera to work
column5:
finally giving up because the batteries are
dead.

6. Bring a shovel to the church.

7. Ask the widow if you think it would do any good to shake him.

8. Put waxed lips on the body.

9. Ask the widow how long she''s been sure he''s dead.

10. Tell the widow alot of his favorite TV shows were cancelled
anyway.

11. Put a bumper sticker on the hearse that says "I''d rather be

12. Ask the widow how long it will be before she starts dating.

13. Tell the deceased''s mother that you never expected them to

14. Put a parking ticket on the coffin.

15. Clam on the body.

16. Ask the widow if she''s going to ride to the cemetery with

17. Hide behind the casket and talk to the mourners as they
kneel in front of the body.

19. Tell the younger children at the funeral that it is
appropriate to sign the coffin.

column6:

costing you a pretty penny."

Three little boys went out to play in the snow and make snowmen.
The first boy came in after just a few minutes. His mother asked him if he
was finished with his snowman already. He answered that he had made a Superman
snow man and it was easy
column2:
because he just had to add a cape.
The second boy came in after about an hour
column3:
so his mother asked him why it
took him so long. He answered that he had made a Harry Potter snowman
column4:
and that
it took a while to find a pair of glasses.
The third boy was out in the yard all day; in fact
column5:
he missed dinner. When he
finally came in
column6: it was after dark
column7:
and his mother asked why it had taken him so
long. He answered that he had made a president George W. Bush snowman and that
it had taken a lot longer than he thought to hollow out his head.

column1: When you''re 47 years old
column2: you sometimes hear a small voice inside you that says: "Just because you''ve reached middle age
column3: that doesn''t mean you shouldn''t take on new challenges and seek new adventures. You get only one ride on this crazy carousel we call life
column4:
and by golly you should make the most of it."

\n

This is the voice of Satan.

\n

I know this because recently
column5: on a mountain in Idaho
column6: I listened to this voice
column7:
and as a result my body feels as though it has been used as a trampoline by the Budweiser Clydesdales.

I am currently on an all-painkiller diet. "I''ll have a black coffee and 250 Advil tablets" is a typical breakfast order for me these days.

This is because I went snowboarding.

For those of you who
column8: for whatever reason
column9: such as a will to live
column10: do not participate in downhill winter sports
column11:
I should explain that snowboarding is an activity that is popular with people who do not feel that regular skiing is lethal enough.

\n

These are of course young people
column12: fearless people
column13: people with 100 percent synthetic bodies who can hurtle down a mountainside at 50 miles per hour and knock down mature trees with their faces and then spring to their feet and go
column14:
"Cool."

\n

People like my son. He wanted to try snowboarding
column15: and I thought it would be good to learn with him
column16:
because we can no longer ski together.

\n

We have a fundamental difference in technique: He skis via the Downhill Method
column17: in which you ski down the hill; whereas I ski via the Breath-Catching Method
column18: in which you stand sideways on the hill
column19:
looking as athletic as possible without actually moving muscles (this could cause you to start sliding down the hill).

\n

If anybody asks if you''re OK
column20: you say
column21: "I''m just catching my breath!" in a tone of voice that suggests that at any moment you''re going to swoop rapidly down the slope; whereas in fact you''re planning to stay right where you are
column22: rigid as a statue
column23:
until the spring thaw.

\n

At night
column24: when the Downhillers have all gone home
column25: we Breath-Catchers will still be up there
column26: clinging to the mountainside
column27:
chewing on our parkas for sustenance.

\n

So I thought I''d take a stab at snowboarding
column28:
which is quite different from skiing.

\n

In skiing
column29: you wear a total of two skis
column31: so you can sort of maintain your balance by moving your feet
column32:
plus you have poles that you can stab people with if they make fun of you at close range.

\n

Whereas with snowboarding
column33: all you get is one board
column34: which is shaped like a giant tongue depressor and manufactured by the Institute of Extremely Slippery Things. Both of your feet are strapped firmly to this board
column35: so that if you start to fall
column36:
you can''t stick a foot out and catch yourself. You crash to the ground like a tree and lie there while skiers swoop past and deliberately spray snow on you.

\n

Skiers hate snowboarders. It''s a generational thing. Skiers are (and here I am generalizing) middle-aged Republicans wearing designer space suits; snowboarders are defiant young rebels wearing deliberately drab clothing that is baggy enough to cover the snowboarder plus a major appliance. Skiers like to glide down the slopes in a series of graceful arcs; snowboarders like to attack the mountain
column38: spinning
column43: getting their noses pierced in midair
column44:
etc.

\n

Skiers view snowboarders as a menace; snowboarders view skiers as Elmer Fudd.

\n

I took my snowboarding lesson in a small group led by a friend of mine named Brad Pearson
column45:
who also once talked me into jumping from a tall tree while attached only to a thin rope.

\n

Brad took us up on a slope that offered ideal snow conditions for the novice who''s going to fall a lot: Approximately seven flakes of powder on top of an 18-foot-thick base of reinforced concrete.

\n

You could not dent this snow with a jackhammer. (I later learned
column47:
that you COULD dent it with the back of your head.)

We learned snowboarding via a two step method:

STEP ONE: Watching Brad do something.

STEP TWO: Trying to do it ourselves.

I was pretty good at Step One. The problem with Step Two was that you had to stand up on your snowboard
column48:
which turns out to be a violation of at least five important laws of physics.

\n

I''d struggle to my feet
column49: and I''d be wavering there and then the Physics Police would drop a huge chunk of gravity on me
column50: and WHAM my body would hit the concrete snow
column51:
sometimes bouncing as much as a foot.

\n

"Keep your knees bent!" Brad would yell
column52:
helpfully.

\n

Have you noticed that whatever sport you''re trying to learn
column53: some earnest person is always telling you to keep your knees bent? As if THAT would solve anything. I wanted to shout back
column54:
"FORGET MY KNEES! DO SOMETHING ABOUT THESE GRAVITY CHUNKS!"

\n

Needless to say my son had no trouble at all. None. In minutes he was cruising happily down the mountain; you could actually see his clothing getting baggier. I
column56: spent most of my time lying on my back
column58:
while space-suited Republicans swooped past and sprayed snow on me.

\n

If I hadn''t gotten out of there
column59:
they''d have completely covered me; I now realize that the small hills you see on ski slopes are formed around the bodies of 47-year-olds who tried to learn snowboarding.

\n

So I think
column61: I''ll go back to skiing. Maybe sometime you''ll see me out on the slopes
column62: catching my breath. Please throw me some food.

column1: Good afternoon all. I''m Al Gore
column2:
and I''d like to tell you a
little about myself.

\n

I know a lot about hardship
column3:
because I came into this world as a
poor black child in a tiny town in the backwoods of Tennessee. I
was born in a log cabin that I built with my own hands. I taught
myself to read by candlelight and helped support my 16 brothers
and sisters by working summers as a deck hand on a Mississippi
River steamboat. Frequently we would stop the ship and I would
cut and split five cords of wood for fuel overnight for the
steam engines.

\n

My mother taught me the value of education
column4: so every day
column5:
I
would walk 5 miles to a one-room schoolhouse. I was a
mischievous
column6: fun loving scamp
column7:
though I never dreamed that one
day
column8:
my youthful escapades would serve as the inspiration for
"Huckleberry Finn."

\n

Back then
column9:
we Jewish black folks in the south were second-class
citizens. One day
column10: a traveling minister came through town
column11:
and I
asked him if anyone was ever going to do something to guarantee
civil rights for all Americans. Well
column12:
I guess I made an
impression. You see
column13: the minister''s name was Martin Luther King
column14:
Jr.

\n

My father was a United States Senator. He once perched me on his
knee and said
column15: "Son
column16: if you work hard and listen to your mama
column17: someday you can live in a hotel in Washington
column18: D.C.
column19:
and go to

win the Heisman Trophy.

column29:
I lived in a housing project and
moonlighted writing songs and playing lead guitar for a little
rock band. You may have heard of us - The Rolling Stones. I''m
the one with the lips.

But there was a war going on
column30:
and I felt I had to serve my
country. So I enlisted in the U. S. Army and went to Vietnam. I
was deeply opposed to the war
column31:
but I did my duty as a soldier
and came back home with the Medal of Honor and the Croix de
Guerre. My battlefield expertise is current requisite reading
material for Officers Candidates to this very day. My being a
wounded female officer serving in disguise as a journalist was a
full time project
column32:
but my military knowledge helped save tens of
thousands of lives. Many cities in Southeast Asia are named
after me to this very day. Statues of me are still commonplace
in many official Government buildings in Viet Nam.

\n

When I got back

I took a long journey across this great land of
ours. I''ve crossed the deserts bare
column34: man

I''ve breathed the
mountain air
column36: man

column40:
I''ve
been everywhere. I''ve hunted all the dangerous species of big
game in five continents using only a handmade spear or my
handmade laser sighted compound bow.

\n

And the people I met at truck stops and campgrounds and homeless
shelters on that journey all said the same thing: "Al
column41:
we need
you in Washington."

I knew they were right
column42:

other business---building the World Trade Center
column44: more reliable nuclear weapon trigger design
column46:
doing the clinical research that proved smoking
caused cancer

and coming up with the recipe for Mrs. Field''s
chocolate chip cookies. I was
column49:
the third (still silent)
partner of Ben & Jerry with over half of the flavors personally
developed by Tipper and me in our own kitchen.

\n

My extensive knowledge of Arctic Sea life keeps me busy in the
research laboratory

but those endangered species need love too!

column1: Good afternoon all. I''m Al Gore
column2:
and I''d like to tell you a
little about myself.

\n

I know a lot about hardship
column3:
because I came into this world as a
poor black child in a tiny town in the backwoods of Tennessee. I
was born in a log cabin that I built with my own hands. I taught
myself to read by candlelight and helped support my 16 brothers
and sisters by working summers as a deck hand on a Mississippi
River steamboat. Frequently we would stop the ship and I would
cut and split five cords of wood for fuel overnight for the
steam engines.

\n

My mother taught me the value of education
column4: so every day
column5:
I
would walk 5 miles to a one-room schoolhouse. I was a
mischievous
column6: fun loving scamp
column7:
though I never dreamed that one
day
column8:
my youthful escapades would serve as the inspiration for
"Huckleberry Finn."

\n

Back then
column9:
we Jewish black folks in the south were second-class
citizens. One day
column10: a traveling minister came through town
column11:
and I
asked him if anyone was ever going to do something to guarantee
civil rights for all Americans. Well
column12:
I guess I made an
impression. You see
column13: the minister''s name was Martin Luther King
column14:
Jr.

\n

My father was a United States Senator. He once perched me on his
knee and said
column15: "Son

column17: someday you can live in a hotel in Washington

column19:
and go to
an exclusive prep school." As a young Hindu boy

these were very
valuable lessons. But life of privilege was not for me.

* I didn''t want people to confuse me with the Pope on TV.

* She''s not THAT young. In Arkansas, the age of consent is only 16.

* Hey, at least she''s prettier than Paula Jones or Jennifer Flowers.

* I had to show the American People that I WASN''T impotent for my second term
in office.

* I was jealous of Nixon with his Tricky Dick" nickname.

* I didn''t leave a message on her voicemail. Get with it. This is the 90''s
column3:
I
sent her E-MAIL!

* See I''m not a Lame duck. She said I was pretty GOOD!

* My real name is not William Jefferson Clinton. It''s William KENNEDY Clinton.

* I couldn''t control myself. It was genetic. I was in her jeans--oops
column4:
I
mean it was in my genes.

\n

* I didn''t insert!

column2:
how
can we get to the other side so we can praise you?" and Jesus

the sins you have committed." So George Bush walks across the
river and the water comes up to his knee. Then Al Gore walks
across and the water only comes up to his ankles. George Bush

says "Don''t worry
column3: he''s standing on Bill Clinton''s shoulders"

column2: campaign ad
column3: January 1992"I''ve offered a comprehensive plan to get our economy moving again....It starts with a tax cut on the middle class."Candidate Clinton
column4: Jan. 12
column5: 1992"I want to make it very clear that this middle-class tax cut
column6: in my view
column7: is central to any attempt we''re going to make to have a short-term economic strategy."President-elect Clinton
column8: Jan 14
column9: 1993"From New Hampshire forward
column10: for reasons that absolutely mystify me
column11: the press thought the most important issue in the race was the middle class tax cut.  I never did meet any voter who thought that."President Clinton

would you go to lunch or read the paper?

Q: What do you have if three lawyers are buried up to their necks in cement?
A: Not enough cement.

Q: What do you get when you cross a lawyer with a demon from hell?
A: Another lawyer.

Q: How many lawyers does it take to change a light bulb?
A: Two. One to change it
column4:
and one to kick the stool out from under him.

Q: How many lawyers does it take to change a light bulb?
A: How many can you afford?

Q: What is the difference between a vulture and a lawyer?
A: The vulture eventually lets go.

Person 2: Why do you say that?

column5: discussing the Six Day War with an Israeli general

column8:
did they know how to charge."

The rabbit reached out

beady-eyed and low to the ground. You must be a lawyer."

and the executioner follow."

column17: the tooth fairy

an honest lawyer and an old drunk are walking down the street together when they simultaneously spot a hundred dollar bill. Who gets it?
The old drunk

column20:
the other three are mythological creatures.

\n

At a convention of biological scientists one researcher remarks to another
column21:
"Did you know that in our lab we have switched from mice to lawyers for our experiments?"
"Really?" the other replied
column22:
"Why did you switch?"
"Well
column23: for three reasons. First
column24: we found that lawyers are far more plentiful; second
column25: the lab assistants don''t get so attached to them; and third
column26: there are some things even a rat won''t do. However
column27:
sometimes it very hard to extrapolate our test results to human
beings."

\n

When a lawyer tells his clients he has a sliding fee schedule what he means is that after he bills you it''s financially hard to get back on your feet.

column1: An aircraft is about to crash. There are five passengers on board
column2:
but
unfortunately only 4 parachutes.

\n

The first passenger says "I''m Shaquille O''Neill
column3:
the best NBA basketball
player. The Lakers need me
column4:
it would be unfair to them if I died". So he takes
the first parachute and jumps.

\n

The second passenger
column5: Hillary Clinton
column6:
says "I am the wife of the former
President of the United States. I am also the most dedicated woman in the world
column7:
a Senator in New York and America''s potential future President. She takes one of
the parachutes and jumps.

\n

The third passenger
column8: George W. Bush
column9:
says " I am the President of the United
States of America. I have a huge responsibility in world politics. And apart
from that
column10:
I am the most intelligent President in the history of the country and
I have a responsibility to my people not to die". So he takes a parachute and
jumps.

\n

The fourth passenger
column11: the Pope
column12: says to the fifth passenger
column13:
a ten
year old schoolboy "I am already old. I have already lived my life
column14:
as a good
person and a priest I will give you the last parachute".

\n

The boy replies "No problem
column15:
there is also a parachute for you. America''s most
intelligent President has taken my schoolbag..."

column1: [surprisingly bi-partisan]''TWAS THE NIGHT BEFORE IMPEACHMENTDecember 17
column2: 1998''Twas The Night Before Impeachment
column3: When all through the House
column4: All Congress was stirring
column5: Even Conyers
column6: the louse.  The Articles were hung by the Capitol with care
column7: In hopes that Saint Bubba would be trapped in the lair.  The Republicans were nestled
column8: all smug with The Feds
column9: While visions of perjury danced in their heads.  And Barr with his rhetoric and Hyde with his trap
column10: Had just settled in for a long evening''s nap.When out in The Gulf
column11: there arose such a clatter They clicked on CNN to see what was the matter.  When what to their wondering eyes should appear But Tomahawk cruise missiles flying like reindeer.  With a Presidential address
column12: so lively and quick
column13: They knew in a moment
column14: it must be Saint Slick!More rapid than eagles
column15: his supporters they came
column16: And he whistled and shouted and called them by name:''Now Conyers
column17: now Gephardt
column18: let''s forget The Vixen!On Barney! On Maxine! I''m no Richard Nixon!!!'' ''From Capitol Hill to the Washington Mall
column19: Now dash away
column20: dash away
column21: dash away all !!!''And then the Republicans heard on the roofThe prancing and pawing of each little hoof.  They scratched their heads and were turning around When resilient Saint Willie scored another rebound.  No longer would he eat from his humble pie
column22: While assaulting Saddam with his bombs from the sky.  A bundle of weapons he had flung at Iraq
column23: It looked once again like Slick Willie was back.His eyes
column24: how they twinkled! His dimples
column25: how merry!His cheeks were like roses
column26: His nose like a cherry.  His droll little mouth was drawn up like a bow
column27: And the hair on his head was as white as the snow.  The stump of a stogie
column28: he held tight in his teeth
column29: And the smoke
column30: it encircled his head like a wreath.  He had a broad face and a little round belly That shook when he laughed like a bowl full of jelly.He was chubby and plump - a right jolly old elf
column31: And the Republicans wept
column32: in spite of themselves.  And a wink of his eye and a twist of his head Soon gave them to know they had something to dread.  He spoke the right words and went straight to his work Hard to believe Mon had called him ''The Jerk.''And shaking his finger and thumbing his nose
column34: '' up the polls he rose.  He turned to his spinmeisters and gave them a whistle
column35: Then they cheered-on Slick Willie as he launched another missile.  They all heard him exclaim
column36: with Impeachment out of sight
column38: and to all a good night.''

column1:
A first grade teacher in a small town in Texas explains to her class that
she is a George Bush fan. She asks her students to raise their hands if they
are Bush fans too. Not really knowing what a Bush fan is
column2: but wanting to be liked by the teacher
column3:
their hands fly into the air.
There is
column4: however
column5:
one exception. A little boy named Mike has not gone along
with the crowd.
The teacher asks him why he has decided to be different.
"Because I''m not a Bush fan" he retorts. "Then
column6:
asks the teacher what are
you?"
"I''m a proud Al Gore fan!" boasts the little boy. The teacher is a little
perturbed now
column7:
her face slightly red. She asks Mike why he is a Gore fan
"Well
column8: my Dad and Mom are Gore fans
column9:
so I''m a Gore fan too" he responds.
The teacher is now angry. "That''s no reason
column10:
she says loudly.
What if your Mom was a moron
column11:
and your Dad was an idiot.
What would you be then?" Mike says
column12: "Then I''d be a Bush fan."

inches from TV camera.
* IRS audit replaced by more efficient reverse body slam onto enema.
* Government becomes a charade of meaningless noises and lots of posturing by
a bunch of inarticulate losers with no class or manners - Hey
column2:
wait a minute...

\n

* Free school lunches destined for the needy instead go to the biggest
column3: meanest
column4:
stupidest kid in each school.
* Sex scandals now involve even skankier women.
* January 20: Inauguration ceremonies. January 21: FDA approves
over-the-counter sale of steroids Newt Gingrich is finally able to wear his mask
and cape out of the house.
* During House debate
column5:
it is acceptable to yield to the gentleman wielding a
folding chair.

column1: Many parents today are concerned that their offspring might somehow be involved in the world of illegal pharmaceuticals
column2: or "drugs".  This is a healthy concern.  Knowing your kids are "high" is the first step toward helping them avoid problems with their health
column3: their grades
column4: the law
column5:
and getting those hard-to-clean vomit stains out of the Oriental rug.

KNOW THE WARNING SIGNS- select the option which best describes your child.

1. Your child''s idea of a fun sport to play is:

A) tossing a pigskin ball around

B) throwing an orange rubber ball into a netted hole

C) inserting a pointy needle into a vein and mixing foreign substances into the human bloodstream.

2. Your child''s idea of a responsible adult is:

A) Bill Clinton

B) Tom Hanks

C) Charles Manson.

3. Your child''s favorite hobbies include:

A) Model Rocketry

B) Baseball

C) Taking white
column6:
powdery substances from a big bag and breaking it down into many smaller bags.

4. Your child''s pet is:

A) a puppy dog

B) a 16'' python

C) a colony of imaginary bugs and spiders that crawl under their skin.

5. Your child''s breath smells like:

A) a fresh
column7:
minty mountain top

B) lunch

C) an opium den.

6. When your young ones dress up to go out
column8:
they look like:

A) Fred and Ginger

B) Regis and Kathy Lee

C) Sid and Nancy

7. Your child would identify Tijuana Gold as:

A) a precious metal

B) a Mexican theme park

C) a good deal
column9:
but not as potent as the stuff from Thailand.

8. When you ask your child how their day at school was at the dinner table they answer:

A) they scored a goal for their soccer team

B) they got the highest grade in class on a math test

C) they scored a dime bag and got high.

Total up the number of times you answered "C" to the questions above
column10:
and consult the table below.

\n

0 "C''s"- Chances are your child is not on drugs. They probably aren''t that exciting either. Kick them out of the house and force them to live on the cold streets for a few months to let them really appreciate life in all it''s murkiness.

\n

1-3 "C''s"- Your child might be on drugs
column11: but you can''t be certain.  Put a flashlight up to their face and flash it in their eyes.  This doesn''t really tell you anything
column12:
but it scares the pants off your kids and is kind of fun.

\n

3-6 "C''s"- You may as well face it
column13:
you''ve got a little druggie on your hands. Your child is a menace to society and must be dealt with accordingly. We suggest a good flaying to help them kick their nasty habit. Confiscate all their stash and send it to Ooze.

\n

7-8 "C''s"- Your child has never used drugs. No sir. Just smile nicely at them and slink out of the house. Never return.

column1: George W. Bush told Dick Cheney
column2: "I really hate all the stupid jokes people make about me." Cheney reassured him by saying
column3: "Jokes can''t hurt you.  They are just made up by a bunch of stupid people. In fact
column4: most humans are quite stupid.  Here
column5: I''ll show you what I mean."Cheney goes outside and hails a D.C. cab and says to the driver
column6: "Please take me to 261 M street to see if I''m home
column7: said Cheney. Without a word, the cabbie took them straight to M Street.  Cheney then rang the doorbell, came back to the car and said, Oh
column8: I guess I''m not there! Take us back to where we started
column9: please."The cabbie did what he was told without a word.  Cheney leaned over and said to Dubya
column10: "You get the idea?  People are idiots wherever you go! Don''t worry about their opinions!"Bush said
column11: "Thanks Dick.  I feel a lot better."  Then he winked and whispered
column12: "Hooboy
column13: was he stupid! He picked us up right in front of a phone booth. He should have realized you could have called instead!

column1:
Why did the chicken cross the road?

\n

MACHIAVELLI: The point is that the chicken crossed the road. Who cares why?
The end of crossing the road justifies whatever motive there was.

\n

JERRY SEINFELD: Why does anyone cross a road? I mean
column2:
why doesn''t anyone ever
think to ask
column3:
What the heck was this chicken doing walking around all over the
place
column4:
anyway?"

column1: Saddam Hussein and George W. Bush meet up in Baghdad for the first round of talks in a new peace process. When George sits down
column2: he notices three buttons on the side of Saddam''s chair. They begin talking. After about five minutes Saddam presses the First button. A boxing glove springs out of a box on the desk and punches Bush in the face.Confused
column3: Bush carries on talking as Saddam laughs. A few minutes later the second button is pressed. This time a big boot comes out and kicks Bush in the shin. Again Saddam laughs
column4: and again Bush carries on talking
column5: not wanting to put off the bigger issue of peace between the two countries. But when the third button is pressed and another boot comes out and kicks Bush in the privates
column6: he''s finally had enough
column7: knowing that he can''t do much without them functioning well."I''m going back home!" he tells the Iraqi."We''ll finish these talks in two weeks!"A fortnight passes and Saddam flies to the United States for talks. As the two men sit down
column8: Hussein notices three buttons on Bush''s chair and prepares himself for the Yank''s revenge. They begin talking and Bush presses the first button. Saddam ducks
column9: but nothing happens. George snickers. A few seconds later he presses the second button. Saddam jumps up
column10: but again nothing happens. Bush roars with laughter. When the third button is pressed
column11: Saddam jumps up again
column12: and again nothing happens. Bush falls on the floor in a fit of hysterics."Forget this
column13: says Saddam.I''m going back to Baghdad!"Dubya says through tears of laughter
column14: "What Baghdad?"

column1:
Now that it seems almost a certainty that George W. Bush will become the
Republican nominee for President
column2:
attention will soon focus upon whom Governor
Bush will pick for his Vice Presidential running mate. It is rumored that one of
the names on the ''short list'' currently being floated in upper level Republican
circles is former Vice President
column3:
Dan Quayle.

\n

For many
column4:
there seems to be some very sound reasoning for picking Quayle. As
was pointed out by one senior official who wished not be identified
column5:
Quayle
"already knows how to do the job
column6:
will contribute gaffes that will deflect
attention away from Bush''s own
column7:
and in a cost saving side benefit will help the
party minimize printing costs for new ''Bush-Quayle'' posters and bumper stickers
(since they can use the leftovers from the 1988 and 1992 campaigns).

\n

Apparently
column8:
part of the overall strategy is the targeting of a key demographic
group that has been virtually ignored in previous presidential campaigns: Senile
and confused voters. One recent survey puts the ''senile and confused'' at
approximately 3.8% of the voting population. The hope is that this group will
mistakenly believe that this is the same Bush-Quayle ticket they voted for in
1988 and 1992 and will once again cast their votes for another
column9:
albeit
different
column10:
Bush-Quayle ticket. The dilemma facing Republican strategists however
is determining how best to mount an effective campaign that will get out the
''senile and confused'' vote. One strategist sighed
column11:
"They''re a hard group to
reach
column12:
let alone give instructions to."

\n

Additionally
column13:
word has it that the former Vice President is undertaking some
unique preparations for another run at the Vice Presidency. Included in his
training regimen is a comprehensive reading of Webster�酶惟s Dictionary cover to
cover as well as listening to the popular vocabulary-building program on
cassette tapes
column14:
"Verbal Advantage."

\n

For many
column15:
the inclusion of former Vice President Quayle on the ticket will
spell ''opportunities''. When one reporter asked Quayle "what do you think about
running on a ticket with a Bush again
column16:
the former Vice President expressed that
he was clearly delighted" about it. However
column17:
Quayle did seem somewhat puzzled
and perplexed as to why Bush has now added a "W" to his name when he didn''t seem
to use one before.

column1: Bill Clinton is visiting a school. In one class
column2:
he asks the students if
anyone can give him an example of a "tragedy". One little boy stands up and
offers that
column3:
"If my best friend who lives next door was playing in the street
and a car came along and killed him
column4:
that would be a tragedy."

\n

"No
column5:
Clinton says, That would be an ACCIDENT."

\n

A girl raises her hand. "If a school bus carrying fifty children drove off a
cliff
column6:
killing everyone involved...that would be a tragedy."

\n

"I''m afraid not
column7:
explains Clinton. That is what we would call a GREAT LOSS."

\n

The room is silent; none of the other children volunteer.

\n

"What?" asks Clinton
column8:
"Isn''t there any one here who can give me an example of
a tragedy?"

\n

Finally
column9: a boy in the back raises his hand. In a timid voice
column10:
he says: "If an
airplane carrying Bill and Hillary Clinton were blown up by a bomb
column11:
that would
be a tragedy."

\n

"Wonderful!" Clinton beams. "Marvelous! And can you tell me WHY that would be
a tragedy?"

\n

"Well
column12: says the boy, because it wouldn''t be an accident
column13:
and it certainly
would be no great loss!"

column1: REDMOND
column2: Wash. - Oct. 21
column3: 1997 -- In direct response to accusations made by the Department of Justice
column4:
the Microsoft Corp. announced today that it will be acquiring the federal government of the United States of America for an undisclosed sum.

\n

"It''s actually a logical extension of our planned growth"
column5: said Microsoft chairman Bill Gates
column6: "It really is going to be a positive arrangement for everyone". Microsoft representatives held a briefing in the oval office of the White House with U.S. President Bill Clinton
column7:
and assured members of the press that changes will be "minimal".

\n

The United States will be managed as a wholly owned division of Microsoft. An initial public offering is planned for July of next year
column8: and the federal government is expected to be profitable by "Q4 1999 at latest"
column9: according to Microsoft president Steve Ballmer. In a related announcement
column10: Bill Clinton stated that he had "willingly and enthusiastically" accepted a position as a vice president with Microsoft
column11: and will continue to manage the United States government
column12: reporting directly to Bill Gates. When asked how it felt to give up the mantle of executive authority to Gates
column13: Clinton smiled and referred to it as "a relief". He went on to say that Gates has a "proven track record"
column14: and that U.S. citizens should offer Gates their "full support and confidence". Clinton will reportedly be earning several times the $200
column15: 000 annually he has earned as U.S. president
column16: in his new role at Microsoft. Gates dismissed a suggestion that the U.S. Capitol be moved to Redmond as "silly"
column17:
though did say that he would make executive decisions for the U.S. government from his existing office at Microsoft headquarters. Gates went on to say that the House and Senate would "of course" be Abolished.

\n

"Microsoft isn''t a democracy"
column18: he observed
column19: "and look how well we''re doing". When asked if the rumored attendant acquisition of Canada was proceeding
column20: Gates said
column21: "We don''t deny that discussions are taking place". Microsoft representatives closed the conference by stating that United States citizens will be able to expect lower taxes
column22:
increases in government services and discounts on all Microsoft products.

\n

About Microsoft

\n

Founded in 1975
column23: Microsoft (NASDAQ "MSFT") is the worldwide leader in software for personal computers
column24: and democratic government. The company offers a wide range of products and services for public
column25: business and personal use
column26:
each designed with the mission of making it easier and more enjoyable for people to take advantage of the full power of personal computing and free society every day.

\n

About the United States

\n

Founded in 1789
column27: the United States of America is the most successful nation in the history of the world
column28: and has been a beacon of democracy and opportunity for over 200 years. Headquartered in Washington
column29: D.C.
column30: the United States is a wholly owned subsidiary of Microsoft Corporation.

An open letter to the rest of America:

\n

America has engaged in some finger wagging lately because
California doesn''t have enough electricity to meet its needs.
The rest of the country (including George W. Bush''s energy
secretary Spencer Abraham
column2:
who wants Californians to suffer
through blackouts as justification for drilling for oil in
Alaska''s Arctic National Wildlife Refuge) seems to be just fine
with letting Californians dangle in the breeze without enough
power to meet their needs. They laugh at Californians''
frivolity. Well
column3:
everybody. Here''s how it really is:

\n

California ranks 48th in the nation in power consumed per
person. California grows more than half the nation''s fruit
column4:
nuts
and vegetables. We''re keeping them. We need something to eat
when the power goes out. We grow 99 percent or more of the
nation''s almonds
column5: artichokes
column6: dates
column7: figs
column8: kiwifruit
column9: olives
column10: persimmons
column11: pistachios
column12: prunes
column13:
raisins and walnuts. Hope you
won''t miss them. California is the nation''s number one dairy
state. We''re keeping our dairy products. We''ll need plenty of
fresh ones since our refrigerators can''t be relied upon. Got
milk?

\n

We Californians are gonna keep all our high-tech software in
state. Silicon Valley is ours
column14:
after all. Without enough
electricity
column15: which you''re apparently keeping for yourselves
column16:
we
just plain don''t have enough software to spare. We''re keeping
all our airplanes. California builds a good percentage of the
commercial airliners available to fly you people to where you
want to go. When yours wear out
column17:
you''d better hope Boeing''s
Washington plant can keep you supplied. There isn''t enough
electricity here to allow us to export any more planes than we
need ourselves. And while we''re at it
column18:
we''re keeping all our
high tech aerospace stuff
column19: too
column20:
like the sophisticated weapons
systems that let you sleep at night
column21:
not worried you might wake
up under the rule of some foreign kook. Oh
column22: yeah
column23:
and if you
want to make a long-distance call
column24:
remember where the satellite
components and tracking systems come from. Maybe you could get
back in the habit of writing letters. Want to see a blockbuster
movie this weekend? Come to California. We make them here. Since
we''ll now have to make them with our own electricity
column25:
we''re
keeping them. Even if we shot them somewhere else
column26: the labs
column27: printing facilities
column28: editing facilities
column29:
and sound facilities
are all here.

\n

Want some nice domestic wine? We produce over 17 million gallons
per year. We''ll need all of it to drown our sorrows when we
think about the fact that no matter how many California products
we export to make the rest of America''s lives better
column30:
America
can''t see its way clear to help us out with a little
electricity. You can no longer have any of our wine. You all
complain that we don''t build enough power plants. Well
column31:
you
don''t grow enough food
column34:
build enough airplanes and defense systems or make
enough wine. This is your last warning
column35:
America. Lighten (us) up
before it''s too late.

\n

Love
column36:
The Californians

"I love California - I practically grew up in Phoenix." -Dan
Quayle

column5: the first person comes to the gates of heaven. The angel at the gate
column6: remembering the new policy
column7: promptly says to the man
column8: ''Before I let you in
column9: I need you to tell me how your day was going when you died.''''No problem
column10: '' the man says. ''I came home to my 25th floor apartment in my lunch hour and caught my wife half-naked and appearing to be having an affair
column11: but her lover was nowhere in sight. I immediately began searching for him. My wife was yelling at me as I searched the entire apartment. Just as I was about to giveup
column12: I happened to glance out onto the balcony and noticed that there was a man hanging off the edge by his fingertips! The nerve of that guy!''Well
column13: I ran out onto the balcony and stomped on his fingers until he fell to the ground. But wouldn''t you know it
column14: he landed in some trees and bushes that broke his fall and he didn''t die. This ticked me off even more. In a rage
column15: I went back inside to get the first thing I could get my hands on to throw at him. Oddly enough
column16: the first thing I thought of was the refrigerator. I unplugged it
column17: pushed it out onto the balcony
column18: and tipped it over the side. It plummeted 25 storeys and crushed him! The excitement of the moment was so great that I had a heart attack and died almost instantly.''The angel sits back and thinks for a moment. Technically

column21: ''OK sir. Welcome to the Kingdom of Heaven

column25: slipped
column26: and accidentally fell over the side!''Luckily
column27: I was able to catch myself by the fingertips on the balcony below mine. But all of a sudden this crazy man comes running out of his apartment
column28: starts cussing
column29: and stomps on my fingers. Well of course I fell. I hit some trees and bushes at the bottom that broke my fall so I didn''t die right away. As I''m laying there face up on the ground
column31: and in excruciating pain
column32: I see this guy push his refrigerator of all things off the balcony. It falls the 25 floors and lands on top of me
column33: killing me instantly.''The angel is quietly laughing to himself as the man finishes his story. ''I could get used to this new policy
column34: '' he thinks to himself. ''Very well
column35: '' the angel announces
column36: ''welcome to the Kingdom of Heaven
column37: '' and he lets the man enter.A few seconds later

column39: please tell me what it was like the day you died.''The man says

column19:
"homeland
security really begins at home." Nickels is actually

BLAIRLY LEGAL

\n

The New York Times recently printed an exhaustive front-
page story flagellating itself for the deceptions of a
Times reporter
column20: Jayson Blair
column21:
while also providing the
first evidence we''ve seen in years that newspapers have any
sense of shame.

\n

Blair was discovered to have falsified and plagiarized
dozens of stories for the Times. One glaring example of
Blair''s deception were his vivid bedside descriptions of
wounded Marines at the Bethesda Naval Medical Center. The
hitch is
column22:
he was never there but interviewed them by phone.
This fact should have been more apparent when he relied on
one heavily sedated Marine''s description of the other as "a
quiet purple centaur with TV coming from his mouth."

\n

Expense reports show Blair was at home in Brooklyn when he
was supposed to be in Maryland covering the sniper story.
One embarrassingly false report that made the front page of
the Times was titled
column23: "Boy
column24:
There Sure is a Lot of Sniping
Going on Here Where I Am. Maryland That is... Where I Am at
Presently. Dang. Look Around at Maryland."

column1:
Spokesman Shows Footage of President Tumbling from Bike

\n

In what some political insiders were calling an attempt to lower expectations in the days leading up to the first presidential debate
column2:
the White House today announced that President Bush has an I.Q. of 67.

\n

"The president is far
column3: far less intelligent than is commonly thought
column4:
White House spokesman Scott McClellan told reporters. Even the simplest tasks remain well beyond his reach."

\n

Reinforcing the impression that the president will be overmatched in Thursday''s debate with Sen. John Kerry
column5:
Mr. McClellan showed reporters never-before-seen footage of Mr. Bush oafishly tumbling from his mountain bike.

\n

"What a moron
column6:
Mr. McClellan said.

\n

The White House spokesman said that Mr. Bush cannot possibly be expected to do well in a debate with Sen. Kerry, who Mr. McClellan said has an I.Q. of 193" and "is widely considered the best debater on the planet."

\n

But within minutes of the White House press conference
column7: Kerry spokesman Joe Lockhart fired back
column8: telling reporters
column9:
"John Kerry is much stupider than he looks."

\n

As evidence of Mr. Kerry''s idiocy
column10:
Mr. Lockhart referred to the floral-patterned windsurfing pants the senator wears while enjoying his favorite water sport.

\n

"His ass looks enormous in those pants
column11:
Mr. Lockhart said. What kind of a moron would leave the house with his ass looking like that?"

\n

Elsewhere
column12: Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld said today that it was unfair to compare the upcoming Iraqi elections to those held in America
column13: "except for Florida."

column1: While visiting England
column2:
George W. Bush is invited to tea with the Queen. He
asks her what her leadership philosophy is. She says that it is to surround
herself with intelligent people. He asks how she knows if they''re intelligent.

\n

"I do so by asking them the right questions
column3:
says the Queen. Allow me to
demonstrate."

\n

She phones Tony Blair and says
column4:
"Mr. Prime Minister. Please answer this
question: Your mother has a child
column5: and your father has a child
column6:
and this child
is not your brother or sister. Who is it?"

\n

Tony Blair responds
column7: "It''s me
column8:
ma''am."

"Correct. Thank you and good-bye
column9: sir

Did you get that

Mr. Bush?"

"Yes ma''am. Thanks a lot. I''ll definitely be using that!"

he decides he''d better put the Chairman of the

column14:
I wonder if you can answer a question for
me."

"Why
column15: of course

sir. What''s on your mind?"

"Uh

and this child is

but nobody

answers immediately
column31: of course

You lose arguments with inanimate objects.

Your job is interfering with your drinking.
Your doctor finds traces of blood in your alcohol stream.
Sincerely believe alcohol to be the elusive 5th food group.
24 hours in a day
column2:
24 beers in a case. Coincidence?? I think not!
Two hands and just one mouth ... now THAT''S a drinking problem!

Every woman you see has an exact twin.
You fall off the floor.
Hey
column3:
5 beers has just as many calories as a burger -- forget dinner!

Bill Clinton starts to make sense.

The whole bar says ''Hi'' when you come in.

You have a reserved parking space at the liquor store.

An old wizard was walking through a park when he came upon two statues. One statue was male and the other was female. They were positioned on opposite ends of the park
column2: facing each other with their arms extended out as if to embrace. The wizard stood there for a long time examining their sad facial expressions until he got an idea.         He immediately opened up his bag of tricks and cast a spell on the statues to bring them to life. Once the statues realized they were human
column3: they quickly ran up to him. The wizard
column4: being very pleased with himself
column5: told the statues that they could finally be together as a couple but there was one condition. He said
column6: ''''Go off and experience with each other whatever you''ve wanted to do for all these years but you must be back within a half an hour before the spell wears off.''''          Wasting no time
column7: they quickly ran off into the bushes. The wizard
column8: with great pride
column9: sat down on a park bench and waited patiently. Fifteen minutes later the two statues came walking back to him.         The wizard
column10: with great shock exclaimed
column11: ''''For over a hundred years you both have bore your passions and now that you have your chance
column12: you come back after only fifteen minutes? Go back to the bushes and continue what you were doing before you lose your only chance!''''        With that in mind the female turns to the male and exclaims
column13: ''''The old man''s right. But this time you hold down the pigeons and I''ll crap on them!''''

column1: Police in George
column2: WA issued a report on the events leading up to the deaths of Ro`ert Uhlenake (24) and his friend
column3: Ormond D. Young (27) at the Metallica concert last Friday. Uhlenake and Young were found dead at the Gorge Amphitheater after the show. Uhlenake was in pickup that was on top of Young at the bottom of a 20 ft drop. Young was found with severe lacerations
column4: numerous fractures
column5: contusions
column6: and a branch in his anal cavity. He also had been stabbed and his pants were in a tree above him
column7:
some 15 ft off the ground; adding to the mystery of the heretofore unexplained scene.

\n

According to Commissioner-In-Charge Inoye Appleton
column8: Uhlenake and Young had tried to get tickets for the sold-out concert. When they were unable to get any tickets
column9: the two decided to stay in the lot and drink. Once the show began
column10: and after the two had consumed 18 beers between the two of them
column11:
they hit upon the idea of scaling the 7 foot wooden security fence around the perimeter of the site and sneak in. They apparently moved the truck up to the edge of the fence and decided that Young would go over first and assist Uhlenake later.

\n

They had not counted on the fact that while it was a 7 foot fence on the parking lot side
column12: there was a 23 foot drop on the other side. Young
column13: who weighed 255 lbs and was quite inebriated
column14: had jumped up and over the fence and promptly fell about half the 23 foot distance before a large tree branch broke his fall AND his left forearm; unfortunately
column15: he also managed to get his shorts caught on the branch. Since he was now in a lot of pain and with no way to extricate himself and his shorts from the tree
column16: he decided
column17: seeing bushes down below
column18: to cut his shorts off and fall to the ground. Upon cutting the last bit of fabric from himself
column19: he suddenly plummeted to earth
column20:
losing grip of the knife.

\n

The "soft" bushes were actually holly bushes and landing in them caused a massive number of cuts. He also had the misfortune of landing squarely on a holly bush branch; effectively impaling himself. The knife
column21: which he had accidentally released 15 ft up
column22: now landed and stabbed him in his left thigh. Apparently

column1: Good afternoon. I''m Al Gore
column2:
and I''d like to tell you about myself.
I know a lot about hardship
column3:
because I came into this world as a poor black
child in a tiny town in the backwoods of Tennessee. I was born in a log cabin
that I built with my own hands. I taught myself to read by candlelight and
helped support my 16 brothers and sisters by working summers as a deck hand on a
Mississippi River steamboat.
My mother taught me the value of education
column4:
so every day; I would walk 5 miles
to a one-room schoolhouse. I was a mischievous
column5: fun-loving scamp
column6:
thought I
never dreamed that one-day
column7:
my youthful escapades would serve as the inspiration
for "Huckleberry Finn."
Back then
column8: black folks in the south were second-class citizens. One day
column9:
a
traveling minister came through town
column10:
and I asked him if anyone was ever going
to do something to guarantee civil rights for all Americans. Well
column11:
I guess I
made an impression. You see
column12: the minister''s name was Martin Luther King
column13:
Jr.
My father was a United States Senator. He once perched me on his knee and
said
column14: "Son
column15: if you work hard and listen to your mama
column16:
someday you can live in a
hotel in Washington
column17: D.C.
column18:
and go to an exclusive prep school."
But life of privilege was not for me. After getting my high school diploma
column19:
I
took a job in a hot
column20:
dirty textile mill. I was so appalled at the treatment of
the workers there that I organized a union. Later
column21:
that experience inspired a
movie - which is why
column22: to this day
column23:
my close friends at the AFL-CIO call me
"Norma Rae."
When word got out what an 18 year old factory worker had done

Harvard called

national championships
column25:
but I also played football and was good enough to win
the Heisman Trophy.
During my college years
column26:
I lived in a housing project and moonlighted playing
lead guitar for a little rock band. You may have heard of it-the Rolling
Stones.
But there was a war going on
column27:
and I felt I had to serve my country. So
I enlisted in the U. S. Army and went to Vietnam. I was deeply opposed to the
war
column28:
but I did my duty as a soldier and came back home with the Medal of Honor
and the Croix de Guerre.
When I got back

I took a long journey across this great land of ours. I''ve
crossed the deserts bare

column34: I''ve done my share
column35: man

I''ve been everywhere. And the people I met at

same thing: "Al
column37:
we need you in Washington."
I knew they were right

but first I had to take care of some other
business---building the World Trade Center
column40:
doing
the clinical research that proved smoking caused cancer
column41:
and coming up with the
recipe for Mrs. Field''s chocolate chip cookies.
Finally
column42:
I deferred to the demands of the people of Tennessee and allowed them
to elect me to the House of Representatives and the Senate
column43:
where I established
the US Strategic Oil Reserve. And then one winter day nearly nine years ago
column45:
I answered the call of the people once again and took the
oath of office as Vice President of the United States.
Since then
column46:
I''ve been part of the most successful administration in American
history. And

I invented the Internet. Many times Bill Clinton

column1:
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

\n

Microsoft Addresses Justice Department Accusations

\n

REDMOND
column2: Wash. - Jul. 1
column3:
1998 -- In direct response to accusations made by
the Department of Justice
column4:
the Microsoft Corp. announced today that it
will be acquiring the federal government of the United States of America
for an undisclosed sum.

\n

"It''s actually a logical extension of our planned growth"
column5:
said Microsoft
chairman Bill Gates
column6:
"It really is going to be a positive arrangement for
everyone".

\n

Microsoft representatives held a briefing in the oval office of the White
House with U.S. President Bill Clinton
column7:
and assured members of the press
that changes will be "minimal". The United States will be managed as a
wholly owned division of Microsoft. An initial public offering is planned
for July of next year
column8:
and the federal government is expected to be
profitable by "Q4 1999 at latest"
column9:
according to Microsoft president Steve
Ballmer.

\n

In a related announcement
column10:
Bill Clinton stated that he had "willingly and
enthusiastically" accepted a position as a vice president with Microsoft
column11: and will continue to manage the United States government
column12:
reporting
directly to Bill Gates. When asked how it felt to give up the mantle of
executive authority to Gates
column13:
Clinton smiled and referred to it as "a
relief". He went on to say that Gates has a "proven track record"
column14:
and
that U.S. citizens should offer Gates their "full support and confidence".

\n

Clinton will reportedly be earning several times the $200
column15:
000 annually he
has earned as U.S. president
column16:
in his new role at Microsoft.

\n

Gates dismissed a suggestion that the U.S. Capitol be moved to Redmond as
"silly"
column17:
though did say that he would make executive decisions for the
U.S. government from his existing office at Microsoft headquarters. Gates
went on to say that the House and Senate would "of course" be abolished.
"Microsoft isn''t a democracy"
column18: he observed
column19:
and look how well we''re doing.

\n

When asked if the rumored attendant acquisition of Canada was proceeding
column20: Gates said
column21:
"We don''t deny that discussions are taking place".

\n

Microsoft representatives closed the conference by stating that United
States citizens will be able to expect lower taxes
column22:
increases in
government services and discounts on all Microsoft products.

\n

About Microsoft

\n

Founded in 1975
column23:
Microsoft (NASDAQ "MSFT") is the worldwide leader in
software for personal computers
column24:
and democratic government. The company
offers a wide range of products and services for public
column25:
business and
personal use
column26:
each designed with the mission of making it easier and more
enjoyable for people to take advantage of the full power of personal
computing and free society every day.

\n

About the United States

\n

Founded in 1789
column27:
the United States of America is the most successful
nation in the history of the world
column28:
and has been a beacon of democracy and
opportunity for over 200 years. Headquartered in Washington
column29: D.C.
column30:
the
United States is a wholly owned subsidiary of Microsoft Corporation.

column1: A group of Texans are driving down the road

killing everyone. The Texans go straight to Hell. When they arrive the Devil is shocked to see that they are not in agony over the heat and he demands an explanation.

\n

"Well
column5: sir
column6: we''re from Texas
column7: and we''re used to the heat
column8:
says one. This infuriates the Devil and he cranks the thermostat up to its highest setting. The lost souls all over hell start wailing. I''ll check on them in the morning and see how they like THIS." He snorts and disappears in a ball of fire.

\n

The next morning
column9: the Devil shows up at the Texans'' camp site
column10: and sure enough they are showing some signs of discomfort. They have taken off their 10 Gallon hats and are fanning themselves. One has even rolled up his sleeves. "Well
column11: sir
column12: explains a Texan, when you have been on a cattle drive in Lubbock during August
column13:
this ain''t hardly nothing." The Devil is now so angry he is seeing red.

\n

"Those damn Texans seem immune to heat
column14: let ''s see what happens when I turn OFF the heat
column15:
he says as he heads to the thermostat. I''ll check on them tomorrow."

\n

column16: and they are all whoopin'' and hollerin'' and drinkin'' the beers from the ice chest in the back of the pick up
column17:
now that they have ice to chill them with. The wail of the lost souls is deafening but the Texans are partyin'' like there is no tomorrow.

"I don''t get it
column18: the Devil says, completely defeated. I tried to roast you and it had no effect
column19:
and then I tried to freeze you and you are partying. You Texans are made of tough stuff. But why are you celebrating?"

Well

column1: In ancient Israel
column2: it came to pass that a trader by the name of Abraham Com
column3: did take unto himself a young wife by the name of Dot. And Dot Com was a comely woman
column4:
broad of shoulder and long of leg.
Indeed
column5:
she had been called Amazon Dot Com.

\n

She said unto Abraham
column6: her husband
column7: "Why doth thou travel far from town to town with thy goods when thou can trade without ever leaving thy tent?" And Abraham did look at her as though she were several saddle bags short of a camel load
column8: but simply said
column9: "How
column10:
Dear?"

\n

And Dot replied
column11:
"I will place drums in all the towns and drums in between to send messages saying what you have for sale and they will reply telling you which hath the best price. And the sale can be made on the drums and delivery made by Uriah''s Pony Stable (UPS)."

\n

Abraham thought long and decided he would let Dot have her way with the drums. The drums rang out and were an immediate success. Abraham sold all the goods he had at the top price
column12:
without ever moving from his tent. But this success did arouse envy.

\n

A man named Maccabia did secret himself inside Abraham''s drum and was accused of insider trading. And the young man did take to Dot Com''s trading as doth the greedy horsefly take to camel dung. They were called Nomadic Ecclesiastical Rich Dominican Siderites
column13:
or NERDS for short.

\n

And lo
column14: the land was so feverish with joy at the new riches and the deafening sound of drums
column15: that no one noticed that the real riches were going to the drum maker
column16: one Brother William of Gates
column17:
who bought up every drum company in the land. And indeed did insist on making drums that would work only with Brother Gates'' drumheads and drumsticks.

\n

Dot did say
column18: "Oh
column19: Abraham
column20: what we have started is being taken over by others." And as Abraham looked out over the Bay of Ezekiel
column21: or as it came to be known "eBay" he said
column22: "we need a name that reflects what we are
column23:
and Dot replied, Young Ambitious Hebrew Owner Operators."

\n

"YAHOO"
column24: said Abraham. And that is how it all began
column25: It wasn''t Al Gore after all.

One beautiful morning a athiest was walking through the forest

natures surroundings...

him warm inside...

He thought to himself that mother nature had made a true and wonderful
world...

The athiest had walked a little further down the track he had taken when
suddenly a bear jumped out of the bushes only a few yards ahead of him and
started growling

column1:
1. The Post Office just recalled their latest stamps.
They weren''t working.... They had pictures of lawyers on them
column2:
and people couldn''t figure out which side to spit on.

\n

2. How can a pregnant woman tell that she''s carrying a future lawyer?
She has an uncontrollable craving for baloney.

\n

3. How does an attorney sleep?
First he lies on one side
column3:
and then he lies on the other.

4. How many lawyer jokes are there?
Only three. The rest are true stories.

5. How many lawyers does it take to change a light bulb?
How many can you afford?

6. How many lawyers does it take to screw in a light bulb?
Three. One to climb the ladder
column4: one to shake it
column5:
and one to sue the ladder company.

\n

7. If a lawyer and an IRS agent were both drowning
column6: and you could save only one of them
column7:
would you
(A) Go to lunch
column8:
or (B) read the newspaper?

8. What did the lawyer name his daughter? Sue.

9. What do you call 25 skydiving lawyers? Skeet.

10. What do you call a lawyer gone bad? ''Senator.''

11. What do you call a lawyer with an IQ of 50? ''Your Honor.''

12. What do you throw to a drowning lawyer? His partners.

13. What does a lawyer use for birth control? His personality.

14. What happens when you cross a pig with a lawyer?
Don''t know. (There are some things a pig just won''t do.)

15. What''s the difference between a lawyer and a vulture?
The lawyer gets frequent flyer miles.

16. What''s another difference between a lawyer and a vulture?
Removable wing tips.

17. Why does California have the most lawyers in the country
column9:
while New
Jersey has the most toxic waste sites?
New Jersey got first choice.

\n

18. What do you get if you cross a crooked lawyer with a crooked politician?
Chelsea Clinton.

\n

Saddam Hussein and Bill Clinton meet up in Baghdad for the first round of talks in a new peace process. When Bill sits down, he notices three buttons on the side of Saddam''s chair.

They begin talking. After about five minutes Saddam presses the first button. A boxing glove springs out of a box on the desk and punches Clinton in the face.

Confused, Clinton carries on talking as Saddam laughs.

A few minutes later the second button is pressed. This time a big boot comes out and kicks Clinton in the shin. Again Saddam laughs, and again Clinton carries on talking, not wanting to put off the bigger issue of peace between the two countries.

But when the third button is pressed and another boot comes out and kicks Clinton in the privates, he''s finally had enough, knowing that he can''t do much without them functioning well. I''m going back home!" he tells the Iraqi. "We''ll finish these talks in two weeks!"

A fortnight passes and Saddam flies to the United States for talks. As the two men sit down

column1:
A farmhand in Australia was out checking farm fences in his Landcruiser when he hit something. He radioed the farm for advice.

\n

"There''s a pig stuck in the bullbar and is still alive but he''s kicking and squealing so much I can''t get him free" he said.

\n

"Okay
column2:
said the boss. In the back of the ''cruiser there''s a pistol. Put it up to the pig''s head and shoot it. When its body goes all limp you''ll be able to get it off the bullbar and throw it into the bush."

\n

About 45 minutes later the farmhand called in again
column3: "I did what you said
column4: boss. I shot the pig in the head
column5: he went all limp and I got him out of the bullbar
column6:
no problem. But I still can''t go on."

"Why not?" Asked the boss. "What''s the problem?"

"Well it''s his motorbike ... the flashing blue light is jammed under the wheel-arch."
