Because every time he opens a gurls legs all he sees is
bush. The ant busts his tail in the withering heat all summer long, building his
house and laying up supplies for the winter. The grasshopper thinks he''s a fool
and laughs and dances and plays the summer away. Come winter, the ant is warm
and well fed. The grasshopper has no food or shelter so he dies out in the cold.

\n

The New Liberal Version
The ant busts his tail in the withering heat all summer long, building his
house and laying up supplies for the winter. The grasshopper thinks he''s a fool
and laughs and dances and plays the summer away. Come winter the ant is warm and
well fed. The grasshopper has no food or shelter.
Shivering, the grasshopper calls a press conference and demands to know why
the ant should be allowed to be warm and well fed while others are cold and
starving. CBS, NBC, and ABC show up and provide pictures of the shivering
grasshopper next to a film of the ant in his comfortable home with a table
filled with food.
America is stunned by the sharp contrast. How can it be that, in a country of
such wealth, this poor grasshopper is allowed to suffer so?
Then a representative of the NAAGB (The National Association of Green Bugs)
shows up on Night Line and charges the ant with Green Bias" and makes the case
that the grasshopper is the victim of 30 million years of greenism. Kermit the
frog appears on Oprah with the grasshopper
column38:
and everybody cries when he sings
"its Not Easy Being Green."
Bill and Hillary Clinton make a special guest appearance on the CBS Evening
News and tell a concerned Dan Rather that they will do everything they can for
the grasshopper who has been denied the prosperity he deserves by those who
benefited unfairly during the Reagan summers
column39: or as Bill refers to it
column41:
the EEOC drafts the "Economic Equity and Anti-Greenism Act"
RETROACTIVE to the beginning of the summer. The ant is fined for failing to hire
a proportionate number of green bugs and
column42:
having nothing left to pay his
retroactive taxes
column43:
his home is confiscated by the government.
Hillary gets her old law firm to represent the grasshopper in a defamation
suit against the ant
column44:
and the case is tried before a panel of federal judges
that Bill appointed from a list of single-parent welfare moms who can only hear
cases on Thursday afternoon between 1:30 and 3:00 PM when there are no talk
shows scheduled. The ant loses the case.
The story ends as we see the grasshopper finishing up the last bits of the
ant''s food while the government house he''s in

which just happens to be the
ant''s old house
column46:
crumbles around him since he doesn''t know how to maintain it.

column47: which the grasshopper bought by selling most of the ant''s food
column48:
they are showing Bill Clinton standing before a wildly applauding group of
Democrats announcing that a new era of "Fairness" has dawned in America.

house and laying up supplies for the winter. The grasshopper thinks he''s a fool
and laughs and dances and plays the summer away. Come winter
column3:
the ant is warm
and well fed. The grasshopper has no food or shelter so he dies out in the cold.

\n

The New Liberal Version
The ant busts his tail in the withering heat all summer long
column4:
building his
house and laying up supplies for the winter. The grasshopper thinks he''s a fool
and laughs and dances and plays the summer away. Come winter the ant is warm and
well fed. The grasshopper has no food or shelter.
Shivering
column5:
the grasshopper calls a press conference and demands to know why
the ant should be allowed to be warm and well fed while others are cold and
starving. CBS
column6: NBC
column7:
and ABC show up and provide pictures of the shivering
grasshopper next to a film of the ant in his comfortable home with a table
filled with food.
America is stunned by the sharp contrast. How can it be that
column8:
in a country of
such wealth
column9:
this poor grasshopper is allowed to suffer so?
Then a representative of the NAAGB (The National Association of Green Bugs)
shows up on Night Line and charges the ant with "Green Bias" and makes the case
that the grasshopper is the victim of 30 million years of greenism. Kermit the
frog appears on Oprah with the grasshopper
column10:
and everybody cries when he sings
"its Not Easy Being Green."
Bill and Hillary Clinton make a special guest appearance on the CBS Evening
News and tell a concerned Dan Rather that they will do everything they can for
the grasshopper who has been denied the prosperity he deserves by those who
benefited unfairly during the Reagan summers
column11: or as Bill refers to it
column12:
the
"Temperature Of The 80''s."
Finally
column13:
the EEOC drafts the "Economic Equity and Anti-Greenism Act"
RETROACTIVE to the beginning of the summer. The ant is fined for failing to hire
a proportionate number of green bugs and
column14:
having nothing left to pay his
retroactive taxes
column15:
his home is confiscated by the government.
Hillary gets her old law firm to represent the grasshopper in a defamation
suit against the ant
column16:
and the case is tried before a panel of federal judges
that Bill appointed from a list of single-parent welfare moms who can only hear
cases on Thursday afternoon between 1:30 and 3:00 PM when there are no talk
shows scheduled. The ant loses the case.
The story ends as we see the grasshopper finishing up the last bits of the
ant''s food while the government house he''s in
column17:
which just happens to be the
ant''s old house
column18:
crumbles around him since he doesn''t know how to maintain it.
The ant has disappeared in the snow.
And on the TV
column19: which the grasshopper bought by selling most of the ant''s food
column20:
they are showing Bill Clinton standing before a wildly applauding group of
Democrats announcing that a new era of "Fairness" has dawned in America.

column1: From a document submitted and published in the Congressional Record on October 1
column3:
by Representative Craig Hosmer[R-California]. The author chose to remain anonymous.

Democrats buy most of the books that have been banned somewhere.
Republicans form censorship committees and read them as a group.

Republicans consume three fourths of all the rutabaga produced in this country. The remainder is thrown out.

Republicans usually wear hats and always clean their paint brushes.

Democrats give their worn out clothes to those less fortunate.
Republicans wear theirs.

Republicans employ exterminators.
Democrats step on the bugs.

Democrats name their children after currently popular sports figures
column4: politicians
column5:
and entertainers.

\n

Republican children are named after their parents or grandparents
column6:
according to where the money is.

\n

Democrats keep trying to cut down on smoking but are not successful.
Neither are Republicans.

\n

Republicans tend to keep their shades drawn
column7:
although there is seldom any reason why they should.
Democrats ought to
column8:
but don''t.

Republicans study the financial pages of the newspaper.
Democrats put them in the bottom of the bird cage.

Most of the stuff alongside the road has been thrown out of car windows by Democrats.

Republicans raise dahlias
column9: Dalmatians
column10:
and eyebrows.
Democrats raise Airedales
column11: kids
column12:
and taxes.

\n

Democrats eat the fish they catch.
Republicans hang them on the wall.

\n

Republican boys date Democratic girls.
They plan to marry Republican girls
column13:
but feel that they''re entitled to a little fun first.

\n

Democrats make plans and then do something else.
Republicans follow the plans their grandfathers made.

\n

Republicans sleep in twin beds--some even in separate rooms.
That is why there are more Democrats.

The weather ahead is good and therefore we should have a smooth and uneventful flight. column8: the chicken did not    cross the road. I don''t know any chickens. I have never known any    chickens. Dr. Seuss:    Did the chicken cross the road?    Did he cross it with a toad?    Yes! The chicken crossed the road

column1: A blonde buys two horses and she can''t tell them apart. So she asks the farmer next door what to do. He says to cut one of their tails off. So she does. But then the other horse''s tail gets caught in a bush and rips off. So she can''t tell them apart again. She asks the farmer for advice a second time. He tells her to cut one of the horses ears. So she does. But then the other horse gets its ear ripped in a barbed wire fence. She is still confused. She asks the farmer what to do. He tells her to measure them. She comes back and says
column2: "The white horse is 2 inches taller than the black horse!"

column1:
So Why Did the Chicken Cross the Road?

GEORGE W BUSH

We don''t really care why the chicken crossed the road. We just want to know if the chicken is on our side of the road or not. Our side of the road is the right side of the road and the chicken is either against us or for us. There is no middle ground for any chicken.

COLIN POWELL

Now to the left of the screen
column2:
you can clearly see the satellite image of the chicken crossing the road.

DONALD RUMSFELD

I have known about the chicken crossing the road for several months. I was investigating why the chicken moved but didn''t feel it was necessary to alert anyone.

HANS BLIX

We have reason to believe there is a chicken
column3:
but we have not yet been allowed to have access to the other side of the road.

JOHN KERRY

Although I voted to let the chicken cross the road I am now against it!

RALPH NADER

The chicken''s habitat on the other side of the road had been polluted by unchecked industrial greed. The chicken did not reach the unspoiled habitat on the other side of the road because it was crushed by the wheels of a gas-guzzling SUV.

PAT BUCHANAN

To steal the job of a decent
column4:
hard-working American.

\n

RUSH LIMBAUGH

\n

I don''t know why the chicken crossed the road
column5: but I''ll bet it was getting a government grant to cross the road
column6: and I''ll bet that somebody out there is already forming a support group to help chickens with crossing-the-road syndrome. Can you believe this? How much more of this can real Americans take? Chickens crossing the road paid for by their tax dollars. And when I say tax dollars
column7: I''m talking about your money
column8:
money the government took from you to build road for chickens to cross.

MARTHA STEWART

No one called me to warn me which way that chicken was going. I had a standing order at the Farmer''s Market to sell my eggs when the price dropped to a certain level. No little bird gave me any inside information.

DR SEUSS

Did the chicken cross the road? Did he cross it with a toad? Yes
column9: the chicken crossed the road
column10:
but why it crossed I''ve not been told.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY

To die in the rain. Alone.

MARTIN LUTHER KING
column11:
JR

I envision a world where all chickens will be free to cross roads without having their motives called into question.

GRANDPA

In my day
column12: we didn''t ask why the chicken crossed the road. Somebody told us the chicken crossed the road
column13:
and that was good enough.

\n

BARBARA WALTERS

\n

Isn''t that interesting? In a few moments
column14: we will be listening to the chicken tell
column15: for the first time
column16: the heartwarming story of how it experienced a serious case of molting
column17:
and went on to accomplish its lifelong dream of crossing the road.

JOHN LENNON

Imagine all the chickens in the world crossing roads together -- in peace.

ARISTOTLE

It is the nature of chickens to cross the road.

KARL MARX

It was a historic inevitability.

CAPTAIN KIRK

To boldly go where no chicken has ever gone before.

SIGMOND FREUD

The fact that you are at all concerned that the chicken crossed the road reveals your underlying sexual insecurity.

BILL GATES

I have just witnessed eChicken2004
column18: which will not only cross roads
column19: but will lay eggs
column20: file your important documents
column21:
and balance your checkbook... and Internet Explorer is an integral part of eChicken.

\n

ALBERT EINSTEIN

\n

Did the chicken really cross the road
column22:
or did the road move beneath the chicken?

BILL CLINTON

I did not cross the road with THAT chicken. What is your definition of chicken?

AL GORE

That was my chicken! I invented the chicken.

COLONEL SANDERS

Did I miss one?

The old man said

column4:
Bush is a post turtle."
Not knowing what the old man meant

the doctor asked him what a "post turtle"
was.
He said

fence post with a turtle balanced on top? You know he didn''t get there by
himself

he can''t get anything done while he''s up
there
column9: and you just want to help the poor thing down. That''s a post turtle."

column1: Bush approved of a new method of testing ready-to-eat meat for the potentially lethal Listeria bacteria found in factories. According to the legislation
column2: ready-to-eat meat will have to pass standardized tests as part of Bush''s "leave no hot dog behind
column3:
campaign. Here is a moral question for you. This is an imaginary situation, but it may
be interesting deciding what you would do.
The situation: You are in the Midwest, and there is a huge flood in progress.
Many homes have been lost, water supplies compromised, and infrastructure
destroyed. Let''s say you''re a photographer out getting still photos for a news
service, traveling alone, looking for particularly poignant scenes. If you were
to stumble across Bill Clinton struggling to keep from being swept away in a
raging river and you had a choice of rescuing him or getting a Pulitzer
prize-winning photograph of the death of a President, what shutter speed would
you use? Q: What''s the difference between Bill Clinton and a pickpocket?A: A pickpocket snatches watches. Three guys, the American captain, an Australian and a Japanese guy are shipwrecked on an island. On reaching shore, the American asks the Australian to find a good spot for a camp. He turns to the Japanese guy and says to go into the bush and get supplies.''I''ll scout the island and we''ll meet at the camp at dusk,'' said the captain.The captain returns to find the Australian has set up camp but the Japanese guy hadn''t returned.''Where''s that Jap with the supplies?'' said the captain.The night passes and still there is no sign of the Jap with the supplies, so they go looking for him. They scout the whole island but can''t find him.Just as they are returning to camp, the Jap jumps out from behind a tree and shouts, ''Surplize, surplize.'' People are wondering what will happen to Afghanistan when we''re finished
fighting there. I''m sure there are plans to rebuild the country
column4:
and a lot of
times with rebuilding comes a name change. These are some possible name changes
the government has been mulling over: Halfghanistan
column5: Pothole-istan
column6: Jenniferanistan
column7: Assbackwardstan
column8: Bye-bye-Talibanstan
column9: Ass-Kicked-istan."

he notices three buttons on the side of Saddam''s chair.
They begin talking. After about five minutes Saddam presses the first button. A boxing glove springs out of a box on the desk and punches Clinton in the face. Confused
column3:
Clinton carries on talking as Saddam laughs.

\n

A few minutes later the second button is pressed. This time a big boot comes out and kicks Clinton in the shin. Again Saddam laughs
column4: and again Clinton carries on talking
column5:
not wanting to put off the bigger issue of peace between the two countries.

\n

column6: he''s finally had enough
column7:
knowing that he can''t do much without them functioning well.

\n

\n

A Safe Bet
column2:
Bush Reassures Nation

\n

In a bold move to privatize Social Security
column3: President George W. Bush today put all of the program''s funds under the control of former Education Secretary William Bennett
column4:
urging Mr. Bennett to "work your magic" on the nation''s nest egg.

\n

Recognizing that many retirees are nervous about the privatization of America''s retirement system
column5: Mr. Bush reassured them today
column6: stating flatly
column7:
"Bill Bennett is a safe bet."

\n

"I have known Bill Bennett for many years
column8:
Mr. Bush told reporters. This is a man who knows when to hold ''em and knows when to fold ''em."

\n

A beaming Mr. Bennett stood at Mr. Bush''s side
column9:
the former Education Secretary wearing what he later called "my lucky hat."

\n

He spoke briefly with reporters before boarding a plane for the Venetian casino in Las Vegas
column10:
where he said he would begin to implement his "can''t lose" investment plan for Social Security.

\n

But on Capitol Hill
column11: leading Democrats howled in protest over Mr. Bennett''s appointment
column12: arguing that the nation should not place an important program like Social Security in the hands of just one man
column13:
especially a controversial figure like Mr. Bennett.

\n

"Why don''t we just bet all our retirees'' money on the daily double while we''re at it
column14:
fumed South Dakota Senator Tim Johnson.

\n

For his part, Mr. Bennett remained tight-lipped about his plans for the nation''s retirement funds, telling reporters, What happens in Social Security
column15: stays in Social Security."

column1:
This test only has one question but it''s a very important one.

\n

By giving an honest answer you will discover where you stand morally.

\n

The test features an unlikely
column2:
completely fictional situation in which you will have to make a decision.

\n

Remember that your answer needs to be honest
column3:
yet spontaneous.

Please scroll down slowly and consider each line.

You are in Florida.

Miami
column4:
to be exact.

There is chaos all around you caused by a hurricane with severe flooding.

This is a flood of biblical proportions.

You are a photojournalist working for a major newspaper.

You''re caught in the middle of this great disaster.

The situation is nearly hopeless.

You''re trying to make a career out of shooting photos.

There are houses and people swirling around you.

Some are even disappearing under the water.

Nature is showing all of its destructive fury.

You see a woman in the water.

She is fighting for her life
column5:
trying not to be taken away with the debris.

You move closer . . somehow the woman looks familiar.

Suddenly you know who it is . . It''s Hillary Rodham Clinton!

At the same time you notice that the raging waters are about to take her under
column6:
forever.

\n

You have two options:

\n

You can save her
column7:
or you can take the most dramatic photos of your life.

\n

So
column8: you can save the life of Hillary Clinton
column9: or you can shoot a Pulitzer Prize winning photo
column10:
documenting the death of one of the world''s most powerful women.

Here''s the question and please give an honest answer:

Would you select color film or would you rather go with the classic simplicity of black and white?

column1:
Did you hear that Hillary Clinton changed her name?

\n

She is now known as "Sharon Peters"!
Tigers really are as big and poofy and soft as they look
column2:
and they purr like a
freight train going by. You find this out by taking one for a walk. To take a
tiger for a walk
column3:
you first need a tiger. Tigers fresh from the bush are not
recommended for the inexperienced. What you need is one who''s used to the
procedure. He or she is thus liable to be merely playful
column4:
rather than actively
irritated. You also need a friend
column5: whom you really
column6:
really trust. The friend
carries an apple wood cane; apple
column7: or some other wood
column8:
which will bend under
stress rather than shattering. This
column9: friend
column10: is your backup
column11:
and the cane is his
or her only tool for everything
column12:
from knocking stuff out of the way that the
tiger is liable to eat
column13: to crowd control
column14:
to hooking on and madly hanging on if
things go wrong.

\n

What YOU carry is a ten-foot length of pass-link chain. This is your leash.

\n

Pass-link chain is the stuff where the links will fit through each other. This
is important. You need this so you can hook on a safety clip. The chain is
looped about the tiger''s neck and acks as a giant choke chain
column15:
but the clip is
there to keep a loop of some sort in case things go badly wrong. You carry the
chain looped in one hand in a peculiar fashion
column16:
which permits the whole length
of chain to be dragged from your hand without taking your hand and/or arm with
it. You practice this beforehand till you''re sure you''ve got it right.

\n

Then you go into the cage with the tiger. Your friend does not. You gauge the
tiger''s mood and put the leash on the tiger. There isn''t a whole lot more to say
about this step except to say that that is why your friend is there
column17:
outside the
cage. On your side is the fact that the tiger knows what the leash is for by
this time and presumably is largely in favor of the idea.

\n

This is where you find out that tigers are soft and poofy. They are also much
column18: much larger than you had ever dreamed
column19:
when you''re standing next to one.

\n

Then you take the tiger for a walk. Your friend walks in front with the cane
to clear the way. You walk with the tiger at your side
column20:
keeping pretty good
control and letting the tiger know that you are Paying Attention
column21:
because if the
tiger thinks you are not Paying Attention
column22: it will do what housecats do
column23:
let you
know that you should be Paying Attention. Unlike housecats
column24:
the tiger is big
enough not to have to do anything truly outrageous to rectify the situation.
Reaching behind you with one forepaw and sweeping your legs out from under you
is generally considered good enough by most tigers. They think this is
hilarious. To this extent
column25:
tigers differ from housecats in that they seem to
have a sense of humor.

\n

It is possible that the tiger will see something that it wants. In this case
column26: the tiger will go where it wants to go
column27:
and your job is to stop it. Wrapping the
chain around something that you pass
column28: as the tiger drags you away
column29:
generally
does this. This will slow it down enough for your friend to jump on top of you
and grab the chain as you go bulleting across the countryside. The weight of two
adult humans will generally slow a tiger down enough to make things manageable
column30:
whereas one will not.

\n

It is not usual for the tiger to react to freedom by turning around and
turning you into fajitas
column31:
though this would actually (at least in the short
term) be an eminently practical thing for the tiger to do. They enjoy their fun
but are generally not ill tempered. If they are they don''t get taken for walks.

\n

They also purr like a freight train passing. Experts in the field claim that
this is not purring
column33:
but you couldn''t put it by
me. Sure sounded like purring
column34: at 16-2/3 RPM
column35:
but it sounded like purring.

\n

All in all
column36:
an experience I highly recommend as a lifetime source of cocktail
party conversation
column37:
but it sort of tends to leave you limp for the rest of the
day.

column1: Looking for savings this holiday season? When you''re out shopping
column2:
take
advantage of the George W. Bush discount. You will need unmitigated gall and
several accomplices. Here''s how it works.

\n

Load up with all sorts of items that you want and take them to the checkout.
When the clerk gets to an item that will not scan on the first attempt say
column3: petulantly
column4:
"My brother says that all these items are mine." The clerk will
insist on rescanning the item. Look bored and incredulous that anybody could be
so incompetent as the clerk tries unsuccessfully to scan the item. Turn to the
people in line behind you and say
column5:
"Can you believe this is taking so long?"

\n

At this point
column6:
the clerk will attempt to enter the bar code information by
hand. Insist loudly that the item is yours and that since it didn''t scan after
two attempts
column7:
it must be free. Get so worked up that your face starts to break
out. The clerk will still attempt to enter the bar code. At this point
column8:
bring
forward your first accomplice who will introduce herself as the Secretary of Bar
Code Scanning and say to the clerk
column9:
"I''ll give you two seconds to enter that bar
code. Ready... Set... Times up!"

\n

The clerk will probably call for the manager
column10:
and the two of them will insist
on manually entering the bar code into the cash register. Have dozens of your
accomplices run to the media talking about possible mistakes and mischief that
could arise from manually entering the bar code. Raise questions such as
column11:
"How
can I make sure the price is being entered fairly when the clerk works for the
owner?" Say
column12:
"These items have been scanned and rescanned. They just want to
keep entering bar codes until they get the total they want."

\n

At this point
column13:
the owner might try to take you to court to get some more time
to manually enter the bar code. He''s really playing right into your hands.

\n

While he''s getting a time extension from the court
column14:
call the office of
Congressman Tom DELAY and ask him to send down a couple of henchmen to lead a
crowd of angry demonstrators into the store to shout and bang on the doors.

\n

Simultaneously
column15:
file an appeal with the Supreme Court asking the highest court
in the land to bring a halt to all manual entry of bar codes.

\n

In the midst of this confusion
column16:
have your first accomplice declare that all
the items are legally yours and that if the owner doesn''t like it
column17:
he can take
you to court. The owner will now have to drive to the state capital to file a
lawsuit in which he will ask the judge to manually enter the bar code of the
item that would not scan. Invite some celebrities over for a photo op and
announce that you''ll share the items with them once the items are found to be
rightfully yours.

\n

Meanwhile in court
column18:
the owner will ask the judge to transfer the item from the
checkout line to the courtroom. Have your lawyer tell the judge that that is
simply not enough
column19:
that the judge needs to move the entire inventory from the
store lock
column20:
stock and barrel to his courtroom.

\n

When the owner contemplates that this will tie up all his merchandise till
well after the holidays
column21: he will surely give up. But just to be safe
column22:
have the
legislature pass a law giving the entire store to you.

\n

Some people will tell you that you won''t enjoy the goodies you''ve thus
obtained because they are not really yours.

column1: A Republican
column2: a Libertarian
column3: and a Democrat are seated separately in a restaurant when a poor man walks in; unbeknownst to any of them
column4:
it is Jesus.

The Republican summons the waiter and asks him to serve the poor man the best food in the house and put it on his tab; the waiter does so.

The Libertarian asks the waiter to please serve the poor man iced tea and to put it on his tab. The waiter does so.

The Democrat then asks the waiter to bring the poor man pecan pie with ice cream and to put it on his tab.

When Jesus is finished eating
column5: He goes over to the Republican and says
column6: "I was hungry and you gave Me something to eat. Thank you. I see you are blind." and He touches the man''s eye
column7:
and it is healed.

\n

Jesus then goes over to the Libertarian and says
column8: "I was thirsty and you gave Me something to drink. Thank you. I see you have a bad arm." and He touches the man''s arm
column9:
and it is healed.

\n

Then Jesus walks over to the Democrat. The Democrat moves far back from Jesus and exclaims
column10: "Don''t touch me!! I''m on 100% disability!!"

����raig Kilborn
LONDON (AP) -- Saucy? The British? Yes
column2: and keeping well abreast of the latest science
column3: judging by a new exhibition of -- er -- underwear at London''s Design Museum. Here
column4: the nation famed for its reserve has raised its hem
column5: offering a peep at sheepskin corsets
column6: barely-there cashmere vests and a glow-in-the-dark bra.Should all the titillation prove too much
column7: there''s also a bra that detects a racing heartbeat and a pair of panties that protects against radiation. ``This exhibit is a compelling statement about British design -- but it''s also quite saucy
column8: '''' said Dame Helena Kennedy
column9: a leading lawyer and chairwoman of the British Council
column10: which launched the show Wednesday.``The perception of British people as being strait-laced is no longer real
column11: '''' Kennedy said. To prove it
column12: the displays are almost as provocative as the garments. Vivienne Westwood''s blue sheepskin corset and ditzy
column13: star-patterned mini-crinoline and Alexander McQueen''s pink satin corset crusted with black Swarovski crystal are suspended inside giant inflatable women''s legs in transparent plastic. Vacuum-packed thongs and Clements Ribeiro''s red silk chiffon panties with polka dots hang from pegs on a washline. Near the entrance
column14: a mannequin sprawls seductively on her back
column15: a vision in pink fishnet stockings and the briefest green teddy and panties by the aptly named Agent Provocateur.And everywhere there are bras to make even 1950s ``sweater girl'''' Lana Turner envious -- from Gossard''s new padded Ultrabra Super Boost in patriotic red-white-and-blue
column16: to Stella McCartney''s tassels and gray beads
column17: to Agent Provocateur''s sliced-away style in sheer black net.For the traditionally minded
column18: there are the more substantial constructions of Rigby and Peller (they put the foundation in foundation garments)
column19: suppliers of spine-stiffening unmentionables to the royal family since the 1960s. Owner June Kenton
column20: personal bra fitter to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and Queen Mother Elizabeth
column21: believes 80 percent of all women are wearing the wrong size bra ``and have two drawers-full of bras that they don''t wear.''''Rigby and Peller''s offerings contrast with the futuristic Techno Bra
column22: made of conductive textile with silicon gel inserts that contain electronic devices to detect heartbeat changes. A British industrial design company is developing the piece for the commercial market and designer Kirsty Falconer hopes it may one day incorporate a personal alarm that will sound if the wearer is attacked. Constructed in a dun-colored conductive nylon and silver fabric
column23: the anti-radiation panties are no thing of beauty. But if
column24: as their makers claim
column25: they drain electricity from the body -- thereby protecting it from magnetic radiation -- can you afford to be without them? The exhibition runs through July 2
column26: then tours Japan and Australia.

column1:
A Press Release -

\n

WASHINGTON D.C. The House Appropriations subcommittee on NASA oversight
column2: in another effort to reduce the NASA budget
column3: passed a resolution today to downsize the solar system. According to an unnamed congressional staffer
column4:
House Republicans felt there has been "too much redundancy in the solar system" and that streamlining the 4.5 billion year old planetary system is long overdue. Such action would give NASA fewer places to go and this would allow the agency to carry out its space exploration goals within the funding profile that the House proposed earlier this summer.

\n

"Look
column5: we have three terrestrial planets" said Congressman Rip U. Apart (R
column6: Del.)
column7: "and only one of them really works! So why not get rid of the other two and clean up the neighborhood?" Most subcommittee members felt that while downsizing was definitely in the cards
column8: eliminating both Mars and Venus was going too far. "We have too many international commitments to Mars." said Rush N. Hater (R
column9: Calif.). "So I think we should keep Mars and dump Venus. Its too hot to live on
column10: and liberal Democrats keep using it as an example of what global warming can do. So from a political and practical point of view
column11:
Venus has got to go."

\n

Also at risk is the planet Mercury which lacks support because of its small size and poor visibility from Earth. "Who needs it?" asked Congressman Newt Onian (R
column12: N.C.). "Have you ever seen it? I haven''t. So what good is it? We just don''t need useless planets. And speaking of useless planets
column13: what about the asteroids? If you''ve seen one
column14:
you''ve seen them all. So I say we ought to get rid of the little boogers once and for all."

\n

However
column15: the downsizing recommendations do not stop with the terrestrial planets. The resolution also calls for a reduction in the number of gas giants which contain most of the planetary mass in the solar system. Most subcommittee members favor retaining Jupiter and Saturn
column16: and eliminating Uranus and Neptune. "Jupiter employs the most molecules
column17: and Saturn has those pretty little rings everyone likes." said Rep. Con Mann (R
column18: Fla.). "On the other hand
column19: Uranus is a bore and its rings are dirty. And Neptune
column20: for God''s sake
column21:
is just too far away. So begone with those ugly bruisers."

\n

But the influential Wright I.M. Fornow from South Carolina has publicly announced he will fight to eliminate Saturn. Fornow is especially miffed by NASA''s success thus far in keeping Cassini
column22: the next mission to Saturn
column23: alive which he feels is waste of taxpayers money. "If there ain''t no Saturn
column24:
then there ain''t no Cassini" he exclaimed. The congressman also expressed concern about sending back-to-back spacecraft bearing Italian surnames to the outer planets (The Galileo spacecraft arrives at Jupiter this December).

\n

The subcommittee was unanimous in its views towards Pluto which they deemed a moral misfit. "Now here''s a planet we can definitely do without." continued Fornow. "A few years ago
column25:
it was farthest from the sun. Now its not. Its just too confusing. And now they tell me its really two planets instead of one. What the hell is going on here?"

\n

The resolution must now be presented to the entire House
column26: where it is expected to pass easily since only a minority of Representatives have constituents on the affected planets. NASA Administrator Golden has vowed to resist any further reductions to the solar system
column27: saying that "NASA has expended considerable effort to make the planets cheaper
column28: faster
column29:
and better. Much of this work would be wasted if the solar system were downsized" stated Golden.

\n

Critics say
column31: that reducing the number of planets will not produce the expected savings to taxpayers. Textbooks
column33: would have to be revised to reflect the new arrangement
column34: and facilities would need to be constructed to remove the planets themselves. The resolution is also likely to draw strong opposition from religious fundamentalists who have long opposed the elimination of any of the biblical planets. Thus
column35: the matter is far from resolved.

column1: Clinton died and went to heaven or to be more accurate
column2: approached the Pearly Gates. After knocking at the gates
column3:
St. Peter appeared.

\n

"Who goes there?" inquired St. Peter.

\n

"Tis I
column4: your lordship
column5:
President Bill Clinton."

"And what do you want?" asked St. Peter.

"Lemme in!" replied Clinton.

"Soooo
column6:
pondered St. Peter. What bad things did you do on earth?"

\n

Clinton thought a bit and answered
column7: "Well
column8: I smoked marijuana
column9: but you shouldn''t hold that against me because I didn''t inhale. I guess I had extramarital sex
column10: but you shouldn''t hold that against me because I didn''t really have sexual relations. And I lied
column11:
but I didn''t commit perjury."

\n

After several moments of deliberation St. Peter replied
column12: "OK
column13: here''s the deal. We''ll send you someplace where it is very hot
column14: but we won''t call it ''Hell.'' You''ll be there for an indefinite period of time
column15: but we won''t call it ''eternity.'' And don''t ''abandon all hope'' upon entering
column16: just don''t hold your breath waiting for it to freeze over."

While visiting England recently
column2:
George W. Bush was invited to have tea with the Queen.

\n

Given his recent political problems
column3:
he decides to take advantage of her years of leadership experience and asks her for her advice. She responds that she surrounds herself with the most intelligent people she can find and lets them do their jobs.

\n

Intrigued with this novel theory
column4:
Bush asks her how she is able to tell if the people are intelligent.

\n

"I do so by asking them a test question" responds the Queen. "Allow me to demonstrate."

\n

The Queen then dials 10 Downing Street and asks to speak to Tony Blair. "Mr. Prime Minister
column5:
please answer a hypothetical question for me."

\n

"I''ll do my best
column6:
Your Majesty" responds Blair.

\n

"Your mother has a child and your father has a child" says the Queen. "The child is not your brother or your sister. Who is the child?"

\n

Tony Blair hesitates momentarily and then confidently replies
column7: "Well
column8: Your Majesty
column9:
I guess it would have to be me."

"Correct" says the Queen. "Thank you and good day to you Sir."

The Queen hangs up and says "Did you hear that Mr. Bush? See how clever he is."

Impressed
column10:
Bush replies "I certainly did. I''ll definitely be using that one when I conduct my next Cabinet shuffle back in the US."

\n

Upon returning to Washington
column11: Bush decides he''d better put some of his senior Cabinet Members to the test. He summons Dick Cheney to his office and says

column6:
you can keep the story."

\n

As he walks down the street carrying his bronze rat
column7: he notices that a few real rats have crawled out of the alleys and sewers and begun following him down the street. This is disconcerting
column8: and he begins walking faster. But within a couple of blocks
column9: the herd of rats behind him has grown to hundreds
column10: and they begin squealing.  He begins to trot toward the Bay

column1:
BREAKING NEWS: GOD OVERRULES SUPREME COURT VERDICT

\n

Bush To Be Smitten Later Today

\n

HEAVEN
column2: ENTIRE UNIVERSE (ANS) -- In a stunning development this morning
column3: God invoked the "one nation
column4:
under God" clause of the Pledge of Allegiance to overrule the recent Supreme Court decision that handed the White House to George Bush.

\n

"I''m not sure where the Supreme Court gets off
column5:
God said this morning on a rare Today Show appearance, but I''m sure as hell not going to lie back and led Bush get away with this bull*#@!."

\n

"I''ve watched analysts argue for weeks now that the exact vote count in Florida ''will never be known.'' Well
column6: I''m God and I DO know exactly who voted for whom. Let''s cut to the chase: Gore won Florida by exactly 20
column7:
219 votes."

\n

Shocking political analysts and pundits
column8: God''s unexpected verdict overrules the official Electoral College tally and awards Florida to Al Gore
column9:
giving him a 289-246 victory. The Bush campaign is analyzing God''s Word for possible grounds for appeal.

\n

"God''s ruling is a classic over-reach
column10: argued Bush campaign strategist Jim Baker. Clearly
column11: a divine intervention in a U.S. Presidential Election is unprecedented
column12: unjust
column13:
and goes against The constitution of the state of Florida."

\n

"Jim Baker''s a jackass
column14: God responded. He''s got some surprises ahead of him
column15: let me tell you. HOT ones
column16:
if you know what I mean."

\n

God
column17: who provided the exact vote counts for every Florida precinct
column18:
explained that bad balloting machinery and voter confusion were no grounds to give the White House to "a friggin'' idiot."

\n

"Look
column19: only 612 people in Palm Beach County voted for Buchanan. Get real! The rest meant to vote for Gore. Don''t believe me? I''ll name them: Anderson
column20: Pete; Anderson
column21: Sam
column22: Jr.; Arthur
column23: James; Barnhardt
column24:
Ron..."

\n

Our Lord then went on to note that he was displeased with George W. Bush''s prideful ways and announced that he would officially smite him today. In an act of wrath unlike any reported since the Book of Job
column25: God has taken all of Bush''s goats and livestock
column26: stripped him of his wealth and possessions
column27: sold his family into slavery
column28: forced the former presidential candidate into hard labor in a salt mine
column29:
and afflicted him with deep boils.

\n

Dick Cheney will reportedly receive leprosy.

There are three guys on a plane
column2: George Bush
column3: Bill Clinton
column4:
and Saddam Hussein.

\n

Bored
column5: George Bush blurts out
column6: "I want to see an apple fly
column7:
so he throws one out the window and it flew.

\n

A while later Bill Clinton says, I want to see an orange fly
column8:
so he throws one out the window and it flew.

\n

A little while longer, Saddam Hussein says, Well
column9: I want to see a grenade fly
column10:
so he throws one out the window and it flew.

The plane lands and the three guys are walking down a market street when they come across an old woman crying and rubbing her head.

Whats the matter?" they ask her.

"I was sitting here tending to my shop when an apple flew from the sky and hit me on the head."

A bit embarrassed
column11:
they continue walking down the street.

A while later they come across a man crying and cursing at the sky. "What''s the matter?" they ask him.

"I was sitting here minding my own buisness when an orange came out of the sky and hit me on the head."

A bit concerned
column12:
they continue down the road until they come across a little boy laughing very hard.

\n

"What''s so funny?" they ask the little boy.

\n

The little boy leans in close and whispers
column13: "I farted
column14:
and the house behind me blew up."

The Geography of a Woman

\n

------------------------

\n

Between the ages of 18 - 21 a woman is like Africa or Australia. She is half discovered
column2:
half wild and naturally beautiful with bushland around the fertile deltas.

\n

Between the ages of 21 - 30 a woman is like America or Japan. Completely discovered
column3:
very well developed and open to trade especially with countries with cash or cars.

\n

Between the ages of 30 - 35
column4: she is like India or Spain. Very hot
column5:
relaxed and convinced of its own beauty.

Between the ages of 35 - 40 a woman is like France or Argentina. She may have been half destroyed during the war but can still be a warm and desirable place to visit.

Between the ages of 40 - 50 she is like Yugoslavia or Iraq. She lost the war and is haunted by past mistakes. Massive reconstruction is now necessary.

Between the ages of 50 - 60 she is like Russia or Canada. Very wide
column6:
quiet and the borders are practically unpatrolled but the frigid climate keeps people away.

\n

Between the ages of 60 - 70 a woman is like England or Mongolia. With a glorious and all conquering past but alas no future (a bit like Tony Blair
column7:
maybe Blair''s a women really).

\n

After 70
column8: they become Albania or Afghanistan. Everyone knows where it is
column9:
but no one wants to go there.

The Geography of a Man

------------------------

Between the ages of 15 - 70 a man is like Zimbabwe - ruled by a dick.

Thank you very much for sending the money

column9: as usual
